description:
Sushi is fresh, and I enjoy eating at conveyer belts! From the conveyer belt, I like getting 1. the edamame and 2. the roll with a shrimp tempura inside and salmon with lemon on top.

I also enjoy ordering the salmon sashimi, salmon skin roll and squid karage with spicy mayo.
author: Andrea T.

description:
Call in advanced to put your name on the waitlist! You'll avoid the hassle of waiting.

This restaurant was smaller than I expected, but I liked the layout. The sushi chefs were in the middle while the seats were arranged around them. The conveyor belt was constantly filled with sushi, and there's a menu you can look at to decide which color plate responds to what price... or if you want to order off the menu directly rather than grabbing it from the conveyor belt.

The sushi was good, and the portion size was decent (3/plate usually). I thought the price was good for Japantown, so I'd probably come back! Eat here when you feel like trying different sushi rolls without having to eat the whole roll.
author: Aileen J.

description:
Wow best of SF. 
Please get Shiso leaf with spicy tuna on top.
We also got the baked oyster, special salmon, negihama and lots more.
6/5 stars.
author: D R.

description:
I've got 3 M's for this place. 

Fish? MOST EXCELLENT!
Rice? Meh, maybe not.
Price? Mucho dinero. 

The fish quality is pretty great. Thicccc cuts of sashimi are available like hamachi, salmon or chutoro. I can easily just eat plates and plates of the sashimi and be done with it. If only it didn't cost so much to get the fancier things...$15 for a whole tray of Uni, worth? You decide.

If you can, get the plates right when the chefs put them out because some of the items, like the oysters, have been rotating around for hours and are very questionable. The temperature isn't regulated so who knows if they even remove the ones that have been sitting there for a long time. 

The rice? A hugeeee miss. It's hard, crunchy and cold. I found myself picking off the fish from the rice. Might as well have ordered the sashimi then. 

The rolls? Easy to fill up on to save a little bit of money, but nothing too special about it.

It's very easy to get carried away pulling things off the conveyor belt. I ended up spending $45 because I wanted to try most of the items. Ended up getting at least 3 plates of chutoro and 1 uni, whoops. 

Overall, not bad if you come and fill up on the rolls and order a few gourmet items. Otherwise, nothing to brag home to your mama about.
author: Nancy L.

description:
Japantown is packed on the weekends. That means that all of the restaurants are packed as well. You can avoid the wait and still enjoy quality sushi at Tenroku.

It's conveyor belt sushi so although you don't get the ambience of eating in feudal Japan like in some other restaurants, you still get a great meal. The quality of the sushi was still good and the prices are more reasonable. It allowed us to still enjoy sushi and venture out and explore more of Japantown without wasting time waiting in a restaurant.
author: Pari P.

description:
Who doesn't love grabbing their sushi from a conveyor?! The many times I've walked through J-town I've never noticed place until I had relatives visiting and my aunt pointed it out. Normally I have tunnel vision when I have a plan going somewhere. We waited about 5 minutes before getting seated. I honestly don't remember the time of day it was but it wasn't all that busy. 

I thought the food was pretty adequate. Some things are fresher than others, I don't know if some of the items that I picked had be on the conveyor for awhile but no #3's to follow so that's a good sign. I like the chart telling you much each plate is because you go nuts on grabbing a bunch. My favorite thing that I got was the toro and sweet shrimp. The cut of toro was so thick and fatty, I absolutely loved it and the sweet shrimp wasn't as firm so it's not the freshest but still good to eat nonetheless.

For sure this is a place I would come by again if it wasn't crowded. I don't think I'd wait long to come and eat here but it will be a fun experience none the less to grab your food from the conveyor.
author: Andrew T.

description: Came here with some family friends on a Friday night around 6:30 and waited for about 40 mins for 5 seats. The restaurant is a rotating sushi belt, with different colored plates that have different pricing. Each plate had different types of sushi and rolls, and had about 2-3 pieces depending on the roll costing from $2.74-$10 per plate. I think that you will get a better bang for your buck if you go to a restaurant that makes the sushi when ordered. My brother and I also saw some of the same plates of sushi rotating for the whole time we were eating. I also think that at the end of the day, i am only guessing that probably have a lot of food that gets wasted. Not sure I would want to come back.
author: Patricia L.

description:
Food was really just alright. Not bad but not great. definitely better than isobune tho! Came here for lunch during the Cherry Blossom festival so it was packed! Lots of places didn't allow dogs unless they're in a stroller...... except here so we settled. Surprisingly, wait was less than 15 minutes for my party of 6 and our pupparroo Peanut. Since we sat outside, we didn't get to do the conveyer belt but it was ok. Food came out in a timely manner and service was great from our waitress June. She was super accommodating, friendly, and checked in on us frequently- never felt neglected from sitting outside. Camie, another waitress, was really nice too and gave my pup a plastic bowl for water. For food, we tried a mix of raw and hot:

- Chicken Karage ($8): Pretty good! Ask for spicy mayo
- Geso Karage ($8): very little portion 
- Snow Crab Roll ($15) not real crab...
- Nigiri's (2pc/order): 
   Sake ($5.25): not fresh 
   Hirame ($4.25): sinew and not fresh 
   Hotate ($6.50): ok. Lots of rice 
   Uni ($7): so dry and warm... tasted like eraser.              
   Negi Toro ($5.25): good 
   Negi Hama ($5): alright

Service was great. But food was just ok. For 2, bill was ~96 (pre-tip) with beer and sake. We definitely left full from all the rice in the nigiri's but not satisfied.
author: Anissa D.

description:
Sushi boats always have a nostalgic feeling to them since I used to go a lot when I was younger. I haven't been to Tenroku before and actually can't remember ever having sushi in all the years I've gone to Japantown. Crazy huh? 

Well, we were recommended this place by a friend and so we came here before starting our Saturday night. First impression- small spot, probably seats 30 people at most. There's like 3 waitresses and the rest of the workers are in the middle making sushi. 

One thing I noticed was that there were a lot of pre-made sushi just waiting to join the conveyer belt.  I can't say how long they've been there but it was very efficient. Not too sure how fresh it was though...this was one thing that bothered me. 

I will say that their seared salmon nigiri was yummy. It was the only thing I ate actually since everything else was doused in sauce or was a basic roll like California rolls. Plates are marked by color for price and the seared salmon is the second most expensive at $5.75 per plate. 

Overall, probably wouldn't come back. Was good to try but I'm sure there are a lot of other sushi boats around the area to try too.
author: Shelly W.

description:
They have kind service. 

Waiting area is not  super impressive, buy hey it's a waiting area. Put your name on a list and chill. I'm just saying they could step it up, maybe some water or something?

I was pleasantly surprised with the selection of goods on the conveyor belt. 
Otoro, salmon Kama, large slices of sashimi and a wide variety of rolls and nigiri. I would say that most of the rolls were California based with imitation crab, but they are good even if they are constructed of average base materials. 

Seems also like they put tabiko on erverything. Be mindful if that's not something you like. 

Space is tight when it's crowded. 

I wouldn't wait long for a seat, maybe 10, more than that and I'd rather go someplace else. It's good, just not amazing.
author: Ben M.

description: This was an interesting experience, a bit underwhelming. It was cool to try out the conveyor belt sushi, but there was not a lot of people there when we ate. It was hard to know how long the food had been on the belt.. Prices are very reasonable, there's a lot of lower priced sushi. Also a few  appetizer and dessert foods in the belt. Sushi combinations were pretty unique, definitely give this place a shot if you're not a picky eater. I didn't feel the sushi was too great, but my boyfriend was slightly more impressed. Service was good, nothing too amazing. You can get in and be done eating in under 30 minutes.
author: Amanda C.

description:
My friend and I stumbled on this restaurant while walking around the center. The place is quite small with the round table in the middle, surrounding the chefs. I've always wanted conveyor belt sushi as there is almost none in NYC. 

The dishes on the belt are priced according to the plate's color. I think there are 7 or 8 price points. Also if you want something that you don't see on the belt, you can just ask the waitor for it. There were a lot of rolls going around. I'm a sashimi person so I was just looking for sashimi. I caught a salmon sashimi dish once and then it never appeared again so I ordered it with the waitor and also red clam sashimi. The salmon was cut very thick, which is okay but the red clam wasn't very fresh to me. 

Overall, if you want to try a bit of this and that with small portion, go for it! But I already know what I want, so I'm not a fan.
author: Hannah V.

description:
I wanna give these guys 4/5 stars because they really do try hard. I used to come to this place often for a quick cheap bite. I only come when it's decently busy only because then I can guarantee the fish isn't sitting out for a while on the conveyer belt. I don't order anything off the menu they hand out only because I know I can get better entrees and apps elsewhere. I do ask the sushi chefs for nigiri or sushi I'm craving because they will make it to order and hand it to you as opposed to watching and waiting for it to come around on the belt. 

The staff there are really nice and they work hard. It's not the best quality fish, but it's conveyer belt sushi. You get what you pay for.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Saw this place last time my friend and I were in Japantown and we decided that the next time we came we'd try it out. 

This place is actually pretty decent. Kind of pricy for us since we usual go to places that have $1-$2 plates but we decided to go for it anyways since this was pretty much our only chance to do so.

We ate in the $4-$5 range which were the yellow and purple plates. They give about 3 pieces per roll but they were actually pretty filling and delicious. I got anything with salmon and it was amazing. We both also went for amaebi which is on a blue plate that was about $7. Not as amazing as we had hoped. 

Inside is pretty small but still comfortable. It's amazing how they fit everyone around the belt. We got seated in that gap where it is easy to watch the chefs make the sushi. Very fun to watch while eating/waiting for food.
author: Tricia Y.

description:
Sells chutoro still frozen and markets it as otoro, rice is stale, etc etc etc

Don't even bother. Tourist trap through and through. Maybe you like burning cash, but most of us aren't VC backed startups ;)
author: Richard K.

description:
Tonight, my son's request we went Tenroku Japan town. The Lady..May be the owner..?? seated us where nobody should be seated. 
In 30-40 mins..From the Sushi bar, Sushi chef to in and out 6 times!! Dirty dishes out one time, Something in to the Sushi bar.  My son and I have to move our chairs to let Sushi chef in and out, dirty dishes out etc. My son lost appetite and so do I. Unprofessional and this lady never said "Sorry" instead "Well, we have to do it and Can't help it!!" So disappointed Saturday night out with my 8 years old son...
author: Kiyoshi O.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by the freshness and tenderness of the fish. They use high quality fish. The personnel is very nice and gladly accept requests y you want and specific type of sushi prepared.

The place is small so the larger the group might be longer the wait to gets seat, but it's totally worth it
author: Hector S.

description:
Me and my family were wandering in the Japan Center and we decided to have sushi for dinner, and we found this place! We had to wait around 20 minutes for our seats by the sushi bar. The server was nice and friendly too.
I love conveyor belt sushi, and this was one of the best I've tried so far because of its quality and convenience! Fresh, seasoned nicely! If want something that was not on the belt, I asked the sushi chef, and they made it really fast and delivered directly to me! Great price for great quality! 
Totally recommend :)
author: Van D.

description:
Ignore everyone giving this place 3 stars or lower. They don't know shit or just don't know sushi. Or maybe they're purposely rating it low so the lines don't get longer. Genius.

One of the best places for nigiri in SF. If you don't see what you like you can just ask the chefs and they'll get you. Sure they serve some mediocre sushi but stick to the good stuff. Seared salmon, fatty hamachi, unagi, uni, otoro... all amazing. Some of the rolls are good too but I usually just stick to the nigiri and always come out happy.

If you've ever been to Japan, this is really the only place that compares (for the price).
author: Chris L.

description:
I think this place is not bad at all comparing to the one outside the mall. I'd go here over there.

I've had:
Saba, tuna, uni, Toro, tamago, seared salmon, hotate and ikura. I think my least fave was the tamago since I expected it to be sweeter and the hotate. My fave  is the saba and uni, I think their uni is cheap here and whoever said the uni taste like eraser, I think it doesn't. 

I'm giving this place 3 stars because their rice is flavorless and they put a lot. I had to get rid half of the rice since it was too big of a portion. Other than that I actually like this place, I would come back if I'm in japantown.
author: Toni Rose M.

description:
3.5 rating.

What drew me into this restaurant was the sign outside that said 2 toro sushi for $7.25! Of course the quality here isn't comparable to high end sushi restaurants that serve omakase, but I can live with it at that price. I liked the torched sushi the most, majority of them were $5.50 for 2 pieces - the torched salmon and the torched tuna were really good, they added garnish on top to add to the taste. The sweet shrimp was good, big piece ($7.25 for 2 pieces). I also liked the bbq eel sushi ($5 for 2 pieces), it was a decent size too - not your typical ayce sushi kind of bbq sushi. 
I would say for a conveyor belt sushi place their sushi is above average. 

Service was good, there was a slight wait but wasn't too long.
Watch how much you end up eating. As the sushi circulates in front of you, it's tempting to keep grabbing them but you have to watch your bill cause it all adds up fast!
author: Debbie P.

description:
I randomly found this place close to Kabuki hotel where I stayed for few nights. Its a conveyor belt type of Japanese restaurant and charge it by the price you pick for sushi plate. They have great selection of sushi,very fresh and tasty. Price is not bad at all. The hot green tea is good too. The ambience in the restaurant reminded of the time I visited Japan few years ago. Why? Not only the sushi and staff, but the space is so narrow to fit all customers even waitress kept touching me and my chair every time she walked passed by. But dont get me wrong,they did their job perfectly. 

One thing I was so surprised was the deep fried shrimp head. Wow it tastes so good and juicy! And yup the Otoro was amazing,melted in my tongue. Will come back again in the future !
author: Tanya L.

description: Delicious sushi spot in the Japanese mall! a lot of varieties and options and a few unique ones like the Kobe beef sushi! Definitely need one of these in New York.
author: Ivy C.

description:
This is a cute place if you have never experienced the sushi boat style dining.  However,  it gets boring looking at the same thing coming around and around.  The price is reasonable as the cut of good fish is slightly thinner than the average.  This may be the way to off-set the cost.  I like the rice, it is not sticky nor loose, the taste is there and many of their rolls are fresh, simple, and not overpowering with sauce.  We ordered few dishes from the sushi bar and they were freshly made, portion size, smaller than the typical rolls.  We also ordered a specialty roll, it was okay, the mayo in the crab meat were not mixed well.  It gave me a chill when I bit into a chunk of mayo. 

You can also order undo, ramen,  bento box, specialty sushi rolls, and sizes.  They do offer a lot for a simple restaurant.
author: Frances C.

description:
My partner and I decided to end our Friday night with some sushi and so we decided to try out Tenroku. This was the worst mistake ever. Everything was fine until we were seated. When we arrived at our seats, we were served ginger for our sushi but we noticed that there were no wasabi. We figured perhaps not everyone is a fan of wasabi so for those who want it, needs to ask for it. To our surprise, when we asked for some wasabi, the chefs looked at us funny and turn around and huddled up to discuss our "request." Turns out, every plate were meant to be served with ginger and wasabi but our plates were missing wasabi. This should have been a red flag but we understand that mistakes happen, especially on a busy night. No big deal.

However, we were extremely wrong. Half way through our meal, we noticed that our water has yet to be served but other guests had their drinks, even the couple who was seated after us! Not only that, but we were also lacking our menu. This was very frustrating because it was ruining our night as we had to ask for everything when we noticed that other guests did NOT have to. You figured that the bad service would end there right? Nope, you were mistaken. When it was time for the bill, I asked the waitress if I could have my tea refilled and she confirmed my request. The bill came but my tea was never refilled. We waited for 10 minutes and tried to get her attention but it was obvious she forgot about my simple request. This is absolutely the worst customer service I have experienced. 

Overall, customer service was a nightmare. The only highlight was that I left with a full stomach.
author: Chloe H.

description:
My sister recommended us to what she called her top favorite revolving sushi places in the city - Tenroku! I've been to a few revolving sushi places and I must say that this place has surprisingly very fresh fish! 

I was really surprised to see that they served otoro nigiri, which I thought was usually reserved for fancy sushi restaurants. But at $7.50 for 2 pieces, it was definitely well worth the price! We also tried the medium toro, salmon, and hamachi sashimi which were very big juicy cuts. Additionally, we had a few rolls that were quite tasty. My sister is a regular at this place too, so she also ordered a few specials that were off the menu, including a seared hamachi with ankimo on top, one of my favorite dishes. 

Overall, an amazing place for quick and fresh sashimi!!
author: Jamie L.

description: It seems like a lot of sushi places in Japan town are just ok. I tried several and wasn't really blown away. However, in terms of conveyer belt sushi, this is not bad. I would say it's significantly better than the bigger place a couple doors down. Small and cozy place. Sushi is fresh and they have some nice premium selections alongside the more generic selections. I love the lid on the plates, it's a lot more hygienic than the open plates circulating around a bunch of people like at other places.
author: Marta M.

description:
Solid quality sushi for a conveyor belt type restaurant. Going in, I wasn't expecting top notch, high quality sushi since it was on a conveyor belt. I was worried the sushi wouldn't be as fresh since it can sit on the belt for who knows how long. However, I still loved the concept and it had decent reviews, so I figured Tenroku was a fun place to try out. It was pretty good. I'd dine here again if I was in the area.

There was a short wait on a Friday night, as to be expected, but we were seated within 10-15 minutes. The sushi chefs and staff were friendly and happy to accommodate any requests for sushi we had, and it was cool that there was an option to order more food from the menu. My favorite was the fresh salmon sashimi! The portions were generous and delicious - I had three orders of this because I enjoyed it so much. I wish I had also tried their toro (fatty tuna). The fiance and I split several small rolls and liked all of them. They were kind of generic rolls and we wished there was more variety to choose from... We were pretty much staring at the same items on the conveyor belt most of the time. I'm glad each plate was covered with a small dish because that was one of my concerns with freshness.

Each small plate is color coded and ranges anywhere from $2.50 to $10.00 or so... We spent about $50 and were satisfied with our dinner. I agree with other reviewers that it's good bang for your buck.
author: Jessica N.

description:
Came here with my friend before waiting in line for a concert nearby. Looked at the Yelp reviews before coming here & so glad I tried this place out!

The sushi was delicious and service was fast & friendly :) A little pricey for sushi however we stayed in the white & yellow plates (around $4) and we found our favorites from the conveyor belt! The place is quite small but we came early, so we were able to get seated right away. Overall, highly recommend this place if you're in the Japantown area!!
author: Adrienne C.

description:
The worst customer service ever!!!
We were waiting in line, the only ones in line, and the hostess saw us!!
No one informed us that we needed to sign in. Who knew if we were the only ones standing there 
Another group came in front of us and signed the sheet so we told her we have been standing here and she saw us standing for the past 10 mins 
She refused to take us. Claims she didn't know who came first. What?? 
We walked off. She didn't even apologize 
They don't deserve our business
author: Chibinko -.

description:
I didnt find this place tasty. In my opinion they have a poor selection of sushi for their belt. 
   Also it is very uncomfortable to pick up a plate covered with easily falling plastic cap
author: Babe A.

description:
If I lived in the city, this would be my go-to sushi place~ the price is unbelievable, honestly. I have tried 90% of the fish they had and they exceed anyone's expectations about a typical conveyor belt restaurant! Their wagyu (melts like butter), o-toro (make sure to specify the "o" for the fattier tuna or chu-toro for med fat), tuna tartare, seared salmon belly, ikura, ankimo (i hate liver but omg this was so creamy), anago "saltwater eel" (it's so underrated! not enough sushi places have this) are the favorites I can think of the top of my head that I plan to get again! 

I suggest going before/after dinner hours to sit at the bar + you get a more personal dining experience with the itamae. I highly suggest ordering nigiri directly from them but the appetizers and rolls are quickly replaced and available for grabs. The workers here are attentive so don't be shy when getting their attention. They also let us bring the bottle of sake we ordered to go.

The sushi rolls on the conveyor belt isn't all they have! I saw someone next to me order a roll that was lit on fire. Can't wait to come back and try what's on the other side of the menu~
author: Cara M.

description:
Came here for lunch on a weekday and was pretty impressed. I wish I worked closer because it's a pretty quick lunch considering you sit down and immediately can eat. 

We weren't expecting high class sushi, but it was surprisingly good and they had a good variety. I think the prices were a little high given the quantity, but it really depends on what you order. The sashimi pieces were really large.

The waitresses were prompt, albeit not super friendly. However the sushi chefs were really nice and willing to answer any questions.
author: Susan G.

description:
You won't find a better sushi boat/conveyor belt in SF. 
Plastic cover over the plates is crucial, keeps the fish and rice fresh.

They crank out so much sushi, the high turnover keeps fish fresh and prices low. Best bang for your buck.
~$7 for 2pc otoro, amaebi, scallop, uni (FOH! half the price of other places)
Their seared/sauced/accessorized nigiri and rolls are proper too.
author: Matthew C.

description:
I tried this place with some friends because the whole conveyor belt thing intrigued all of us. The place itself is cramped (Japantown- that's understandable) so I was careful not to knock other customers while trying to get to my seat. 

There is a color legend that tells the price of each plate and each plate is color coded. There are covers on the food items on the conveyor belt so that's a plus! It would be so so so much helpful if there were actual tags that said what each item was made of, ie. what kind of fish and other goodies are in the sushi. That would've helped me with my selection because, I have to admit, my sushi game ain't there yet where I see something and automatically know what's what. 

The sushi was ok but not amazing. It seemed like the chefs weren't putting new sushi out, so some pieces looked like they were giving up on life since they've been a while on the conveyor belt...

Overall, it's a nice little place to sit down, nibble on some sushi and talk to friends. I'll have to try the hot menu items if I ever go again. I also got some cool instagram boomerang shots of the sushi conveyor belt. Everyone's into food posts these days.
author: Cassandra P.

description:
ZERO STARS.

I'm very disappointed with the food and service. Came here on a Sunday with family 7 and it was light-weight packed inside, so we decided to sit outside. This type of dining is sushi on a conveyor belt but since there was no room for all of us to sit together, I asked if they can bring the food out to us --server said "Yes". After looking at the menu, we all decided on Ramen.

FOOD: RAMEN

My mom and aunt ordered the beef udon -- they found it salty. My aunt did not want to hassle them so she is just asked the server for hot water so she can water down the broth. I mentioned the salty broth when the server went to fetch the hot water but she ignored my comment (one star knocked off).

The rest of us ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen -- flavor was bland, noodles were thin and comparable to American Top Ramen Noodle quality, topped off with Chicken Katsu and 2 slices of white raddish with the pink edges. (NO EGG! -- that's my favorite part of about eating Ramen) Me and my sister had a few bites and it just didn't taste right. I really wanted to give the food a chance but I could get myself to swallow the noodles. Forcing myself to eat it made it taste worse.

SERVICE: HORRID

Here's the best part -- server never checked on our table, we had to waive them down each time. Our food took forever to arrive -- and when it did, the timing was far apart from each other's order. (two stars knocked off). When we flagged down the server to inform her of our blandness and poorly made ramen, she said "I'm sorry" takes our bowls and walks off. Did not even give us options for something else nor did she wanted to know why we didn't like them. Our bowls were still FULL to the top and you aren't curious as to why we asked for you to take them back?? (see my photos) AND, it wasn't just one person -- TWO of us brought it to your attention. This is a $12 bowl of Ramen so I expect the quality to match up. (two stars knocked off)My brothers were disappointed with the service when the two of us inquired so they just forced the noodles down.

They had the audacity to add it to our bill (once again, we had to flag them down to obtain our bill). When I questioned the server --"What do you do when your customers are dissatisfied with their food?" Her response "everyone has different taste" and left it at that -- are you kidding me? I asked her once again in another way "What is the protocol when a customer doesn't like their food?" -- she grabbed the second server, stared at the her hoping she could respond to her or give us a response. After an awkward minute of staring and no response. Then I politely asked to speak to their manager, she responds "No manager is here today." Me: "Ok... who can I talk to?" Server: "Uh.. we are all equals here" -- so she was indirectly telling me that there was no supervisor on duty but that didn't answer my question. Again, the 2 servers stared at each other hoping one of the two would step up and respond to us (awkward silence) mumbled something under their breath and walked off. (3 stars knocked off).

At this point I was upset, but I remained calm. I just wanted to know what is their protocol for a dissatisfied customer. We were still going to pay for the ramen even if I only took 3 bites of it. Within a few minute, the server scurries to our table and says "we'll cancel your order" and rushes away with our bill and brings back the revised bill and change - NO EYE CONTACT --we are not trying to harm nor hurt you, we just wanted to express our concerns. But it looks like they took it personally (any more stars to knock off?)

These servers were young and inexperienced -- I blame their supervisor for not training them properly with customer service or establishing a protocol to invite feedback. How would do you expect your business to grow without customer feedback? Even though this is not a Ramen House -- I expected the food quality and service to be up to par with their prices. I WILL NOT BE RETURNING, NOT EVEN TO TRY THE SUSHI. Not worth my money.
author: Luc L.

description:
I was so underwhelmed by this place and I personally LOVE sushi trains. 

It didn't take long for us to sit with a group of four which was probably the main upside of this place. None of the dishes are labeled on the train which makes it hard to pick a plate and when you do it's likely you'll have grabbed a roll you didn't want.

It was also on the pricier side. Most rolls that we're on the conveyer belter we're 4-5 each. So to really get a you'll meal for me would be 4 plates and you're already at 20 dollars before tip. I've been to similar restaurants with cheaper plates that I thought were higher quality.

The service was also inconsistent. My friend I was with ordered a roll and as we were getting the check it finally came. He thought they had just forgot about it so he was left with a $15 dollar roll he really didn't want.
author: Maddie M.

description:
Good not great sushi on a conveniently designed conveyor belt. Japantown was brimming with people and this place was packed ! I had to deal with a 15 minute wait. The quality of fish wasn't dramatically better than the sushi boat place nearby Isobune. But it was good! Once again good not great. The uni tonight was kind of musty and wasn't the proper texture.  
I had better before elsewhere.  
Hamachi was not properly or fully thawed and flavorless.  
Service was functional not exceptional 
  Beer was cold
Don't expect top shelf here
You will get a decent sushi
It's sister restaurant on 19th and Taraval is preferable for my tastes
JYW says try it and decide for yourself.
author: Jeff W.

description:
A notch better than Isobune, but that's not really saying much. 

The staff are SO nice and we appreciate their hard work. But the sushi on that conveyor belt that goes round and round and round hypnotizing you ... don't do it. I did not. I was skeptical. 

Instead, I stuck with something deep fried and cooked through: tempura shrimp and veggies. I also had a taste of Peter L's chasu ramen. (skip!) 

You'll probably end up here coz you're desperate and hungry. 

And Festa is closed.
author: Janice C.

description:
In terms of price-to-quality ratio and convenience, Tenroku is my absolute favorite sushi place in San Francisco. 

I love that I can just go in, sit down, and immediately start grabbing plates without any wait. For their price, the quality is very good and they usually have an excellent variety going around too, including interesting combinations I've never seen at any other sushi place.

Some of their best plates: $8(!!!)otoro, uni, ikura with quail egg, unagi, oysters, and any of their seared sushi.

In comparison to the other conveyor belt sushi place in the same mall, Isobune, I definitely recommend Tenroku over it. Tenroku's plates are overall cheaper but, in my opinion, also higher quality. I also prefer their conveyor belt over Isobune's since it is slower and you can see dishes on the other side of the belt, giving you ample time to decide what you want to get. 

Their sushi chefs, especially Cesar, are all incredibly friendly and will gladly make anything you ask for.

Not a great place for large groups since it is mostly seats at the counter around the belt. I have never had anything for their menu (I've only eaten from the sushi belt) so I cannot comment on that. They serve decent free tea as well.
author: Eric L.

description: Pretty standard conveyor belt sushi quality. I think the best pieces come if you order them directly rather than picking them up from the belt. Loved the hirame, toro, and tamago. I was skeptical at first but when I put that piece of toro in my mouth I knew that this place didn't skimp out on all fish quality. Solid prices, good eats, good service
author: David Y.

description: What's not to like about conveyer belt sushi ? What you see is what you get.. and I thought this place was definitely a quality higher than other revolving sushi restaurants I've been to . The fish is ultra fresh and cut to the correct thickness .. some plates are a bit pricey but range from about 3-10 dollars depending . They have higher end dishes like uni and sweet raw Ebi.. those were 10/ plate . Their salmon nigiri really hit the spot and the pieces were large and generous . I really chowed those down. Overall I liked this unpretentious restaurant.. It was convenient fast and delicious . you can hop in here for a quick snack or stay and let your plates pile up .. plus it was fun watching the workers make your sushi right in front of  you. nothing here  seemed to be old / dried out from being prepared the day before .
author: Thang S.

description: Not so good.  Some of the sushi didn't seem fresh.  Nothing really stood out except the sushi chef who looked more like a Brooklyn cab driver from the 50s (even though we may have heard him speak Japanese so I don't know what to think).  The prices were fair.
author: Scott H.

description:
Pros:
Conveyer belt Sushi means different Sushi to try! Also, with three people, we were sat at the bar fairly quickly for a Saturday night at ~6:30pm. The appetizers (gyoza, tempura) and sushi on the conveyer belt were pretty delicious!

Cons:
The price per small plate were pretty expensive (ranged from $2.75 - $10) and most of the small plates on the conveyer belt were $5 or more. Each small plate only had 2-3 pieces of sushi (4 if lucky). We left around 7:30, which is when is started getting busy so I'm not sure how long the wait would be on a certain days.
author: Jessa May C.

description: I been there two times but the food is nothing special here. The fish is not the best qualty as well as variety. Love the idea of conveyer belt though.
author: Lizzz K.

description: This is hands down the best sushi I've had in a long time! Amazing prices - great service - authentic atmosphere! Truly will always recommend this place - it's def off the beaten path and unusual than most places ! You can watch your food being made right in front of you. Complimentary tea is served with your meal. Every bite was delicious and amazing ! Can't wait to go back!
author: Sara D.

description: Do you like your sushi fresh, thicc and delish? Head to Tenroku for the best salmon sashimi, kobe beef nigiri, crispy salmon skin roll, tuna sashimi...the list goes on! The chefs prepare the sushi in front of your eyes, so you know exactly what is going into your food. And who doesn't love sushi belts?
author: Seerat J.

description:
Typical San Francisco, people complain about water served late or their seating inconvenient.  Ding the restaurant gets one star.  
If you came for the fish, and that's kinda the point for sushi boat, that place serves generous portions.  It is fresh, tasty with a lot of choice and price reasonably.
author: Mixie D.

description:
First time having conveyer belt sushi in japan town

I must say I'm starting to enjoy sushi more than any other food in the world 


They have great selection of sushi and the line isn't long

You'll be seated really fast
author: Chiu H.

description:
Synopsis: sushi on conveyer belt was so-so. Sushi orders placed through waitress were significantly better. No water refills. Crammed seating and absolutely no customer service @ all. 

I haven't been to a conveyer belt sushi restaurant since living abroad in Singapore (around 2008). I have passed this restaurant on my way to pika-pika (multiple photo booth shop) and never dared to try it out. Today, I figured to go in with my boyfriend and try their sushi out.

By default you're seated @ the sushi bar / conveyer belt unless you request for a table. It takes away from the experience and reason to come into the restaurant. 

There really wasn't many plates out that looked appetizing or worth "the grab." Eventually the chef put out some dishes and they were snatched up pretty fast. I can't tell you the exact Rolls we had except the two Spider rolls i ordered with our waitress.

Our waitress never came to refill our water cups nor did she ask us if we wanted any other rolls. It was frustrating because everyone on my left and right had no water. This restaurant is small in size so getting to customers wasn't much of a hassle.

I checked in from the moment I walked in but didn't scroll to read the 'warning- poor food...' 

I understand the whole idea of sushi sitting on plates for x amount of hours... & how it may deter people from this restaurant. I didn't have an excellent experience, so I can't say I'll be back. Stomach feels strange after 30 minutes of leaving the restaurant. Hopefully it's nothing serious. Eeee
author: Christina L.

description: Located on the second floor of a mall next to a movie theater. The place is incredibly small, the service is fast. Sushi selection was okay but the price was right if you don't want to spend so much for sushi.
author: Cynthia L.

description: The sushi is pretty fresh especially the uni and sweet shrimp. The place is small, but seems like the turn around time is pretty quick.
author: Philip T.

description:
We had family visiting from out of town on a random Monday in the summer.  After hanging out at the Walt Disney museum, we headed over to Japan town to grab some sushi.  After walking around the area, we settled on Tenroku.  We had a party of 8 (4 adults and 4 kids), and the space is a bit small so we sat at the tables in front and did not sit in front of the conveyor belt.  The waitresses were very helpful and told us we can walk up to the sushi boat area and bring the items back to our table. 

We ordered a few things off the menu and then took turns heading to the sushi boat area and bringing the items back to our table.   The sushi was actually surprisingly good.  My husband loved their blue fin tuna and I loved their rolls.  My little one loved their beef teriyaki and finished his whole plate which is not common unless his food is really good.  We also shared a bottle of large sake amongst the group.   

We had such an enjoyable experience that my family and I returned to the restaurant the following week.  The sushi plates can add up so make sure you are keeping tabs in case.  We made that mistake and before we knew it, ended up with a bill of over $100 for 2 people, 1 child.  Still, totally worth it.  We will return again soon.
author: Christine P.

description: Cute little place underneath Japan town. It's like a sushi boat without the boat. It revolves around on a conveyer belt. They only serve bluefin tuna. Absolutely melts in your mouth. Good find.
author: Dan C.

description:
I always loved conveyer belt sushi restaurants. My boyfriend told me about this place and we decided to try it for dinner. Usually there will be a long line, but thankfully we didn't have to wait that day (probably cause everyone went to catch Pokemon). Service was great and staff was friendly.

They have a good amount of different sushi and styles rotating. Prices are decent, not too pricey at all. The sushi itself is OK, it's not the freshest and the best. Some of the fatty toro tasted kinda icey...eh. I mean you pay for what you ask for. It is a decent places for a quick sushi fix, but do not expect extraordinary.
author: Natalie L.

description: My boyfriend and I came here last night. He has food poisoning now! I do not have food poisoning because I did not consume a lot of raw fish. Not good and will not be returning.
author: Monica L.

description:
AVOID AVOID AVOID... the poor food safety alert alone should have been a clear sign to stay away... 

So the idea of a sushi belt is great and it wold be amazing only if the sushi is fresh... we came in on a late weekday afternoon and the place was relatively empty. We got seated right away. Aside from the food, the staff is friendly and the chefs behind the belt are a fun group. Its the food thats an issue. 

Now with sushi, you want your fish to fresh all the time, here however, the sushi is not fresh. All the raw fish offerings look grey and felt warm to the touch. The fish was not fresh and when you have a sushi circling around the belt over and over , you need to remove it and put out fresh sushi instead. They did not do that. The same sushi pieces were rotating on the belt over and over until some poor soul grabbed that old piece and then the chefs finally placed a new sushi order out. 

The sushi here did not taste great either and for the price you pay it is not worth it. Each plate is color coded for price and 4 pieces of spicy salmon can run you the same price as a regular 8 piece order at any other sushi place. 

Maybe its the idea of the sushi belt that drew us in BUT the quality and poor treatment of the sushi kicked us out quick, we only stayed for 2 plates and left ASAP.
author: Vincent T.

description: I'd suggest staying a way from this place.  The sushi here is decent at best.  The fish didn't seam fresh or maybe just lower quality.  The lids covering the sushi are dirty.  The plates are not refrigerated so who knows how long some of those have sitting out there.  The sushi chef spent more chatting up and hooking it up with his friends that came in then helping customers.
author: Aaron S.

description:
$10 for a slab of uni and $7 for two pieces of o-toro! Yes, please!

The specials lured me in.

That and the seared hamachi with ankimo for $4.75.

I literally came here for the specials and loaded up on them alone.

Typical boat place, usually not crowded unless it's the weekend or tourist season.

The uni was fresh, and the o-toro was good for what it was. As long as you stick to the specials you'll be saving money.

Everything else is regular sushi boat prices, so I skipped that.

Priorities you know!
author: Jack R.

description: Can't believe they serve expired food! It was a sushi that has crab meat mixed with something like cream and it was rotten!!!!!! OMG! And when we told it about the female manager, she didn't say anything not even a sorry! She just took away the plate.........
author: Qiu J.

description: I am in a food poisoning all because yesterday's crab meat sushi in this restaurant. I reacted the smelly crab meat sushi but I still have swallowed a little bit and I gathe green dish to the waiter and she even didn't give me an apology and right now I am in the pain and full of angry! I won't go to the this shitty place anymore!
author: Cha S.

description:
Really nice sushi place, no problems so far after going here for no less than 5 times already!

I guess it must have been that I went there on weekday nights, but there was very little wait and we promptly got a table as soon as there was seats available. 

Sushi's great, no complaints so far. Staff are nice and very helpful. I never felt rushed eating here, I can stay 20-30 minutes and get some pretty good sushi, nigiri or other stuff they place at their conveyor belt.
author: Jegy G.

description: Terrible service. Got a hair on one of the plate and give it to a lady and she just take the plate and put it back in the kitchen. Didn't even say sorry or do anything. Just pretend nothing happen. Ask another lady for the bill and she never give me the bill. End up need to ask the lady who I give the plate with the hair to give me the bill. It took them 30 min to give me my bill which I only have 11 plates. Take them 15 min to process my bill and return it back to me. Will never ever return to this dam sushi restaurant. The whole restaurant is terrible and bad. If I can I wouldn't even give them a star rate. Overall score I will give this restaurant is -100.
author: Melinda L.

description:
We came here on a Saturday night and all the Japanese restaurants in the building were pretty crowded in general. 

We waited about half an hour for 3 counter seats and there was still a queue outside the restaurant when we left at about 7pm. 

We ordered the beef udon and had various nigiri/sashimi. While some of the sashimi (salmon, sweet shrimp) was pretty fresh, I had to knock a star off due to the price. $5.25-7 for 2-slice sashimi plates are quite steep for conveyor belt sushi here. 

But this review might not be fair. I remember days of distant past where I pigged out on stacks of conveyor belt sushi plates in Japan which experience was waaaay better for a lower price.
author: Lindt C.

description: Sushi boats are always very fun as you get a lot of variety and you can pick and choose as the boat circulates through. Service is always subpar when it comes to getting drink orders in but thankfully you don't have to deal with the waitresses to get food. I highly recommend their seared salmon belly. You get a nice charred tasted on top of liquefying fat that melts into your mouth. Their real crab Kani is also delicious if you are craving something on the creamier side. Their block of Uni is just $10 here but make sure you check it out before you get it. It's always a hit or miss with this place for Uni. Yes, it is expensive but I personally think it's worth the money you pay.
author: Ada H.

description:
I like this place because of their... 
-Convenient location
-Sushi making skills
-Torched fatty salmon, Halibut and uni, Butter Fish!!!  Best when prepared upon request.

But I don't like this place because of this message...
(Consumer Alert: Poor Food Safety Score!  Following a recent inspection, this facility received a food safety rating that is in the bottom 5% locally, and is categorized by inspectors as poor.)

I'm so torn.  

Oh well, I hope they get their act together.  For now, I'll skip the conveyor belt.  But when I crave that mouthwatering butter fish or fatty salmon, it's a risk that I'll have to take!  Yes, it's that good...especially when made in front of me.   

#YOLO
author: Bobby L.

description:
Who knew conveyer belt sushi could be so good! My friends introduced me to the salmon toro and I couldn't get enough of it. It was amazingly soft and fatty.
I also tried the unagi, which were very sizable soft pieces for cheap.
The halibut was extremely white and topped with uni. 

The nice thing is almost every seat is a bar seat. We get to watch the chefs prepare the sushi right in front of us. Watching the chef skin and filet a yellowtail was fascinating. He worked with such speed and precision. 

Prices are determined by the pattern and color on the plate. There is a handy picture guide that lists the price.
author: Edward W.

description:
A solid sushi snack place for a quick meal of tempura, sushi, sake etc. They have a conveyor belt but I always order off the menu. The service is friendly and it's relatively cheap.
Sushi tasted fresh. AOK
author: Jordan C.

description: This place is below average. The chefs are hispanic...not Japanese. Not that I'm against that...but you would think a location in Japantown would be more authentic. The tuna was bad...and made me sick. I actually threw up when I got home. The salmon was the only fresh fish. The bill for 2 was 75.00 and a sheer waste of money. Skip this place and go eat ramen. Not going back.
author: Ellen B.

description: This place was pretty great. Fast service, friendly staff and no need to even mention the sushi chefs. The food was of very good quality, much better than what I expected from a conveyor belt sushi place. Everything was delicious, and I strongly recommend the charcoal grilled fish for anyone going.
author: Andrey L.

description: Good fish cuts. Very fresh and if you go when it's a full house you don't have to worry about plates that have been sitting out for a long time. It is not the cheap alternative conveyor belt sushi that sucks, it is moderately priced for fresh fish so it can get pricey if you don't watch what you're eating. Overall it is not super expensive considering how fresh the fish are.
author: Sarah L.

description:
The place itself is really cute and is a typical kaitenzushi style.

The service and food on the other hand is a hit or miss.

My boyfriend really enjoyed one of the sushi plates from the conveyor belt.  According to him they used really good quality caviar on one of their sushi dishes. 

The eel ramen he had wasn't good, he ate maybe a quarter of it and then stopped. He's a 6 foot tall hungry dude, and the fact that he didn't even bother finishing eating the bowl of ramen is a bad sign. This guy eats everything and anything but refused to eat the ramen...

The unagi-don(eel with rice) bowl I had was TERRIBLE.  They did not completely cook the eel, so the middle was rubbery and too chewy to consume.  Unagi is supposed to be soft and tender, not rubbery!  

I ate around the edges but couldn't finish the 3 pieces because of it being terribly under-cooked. Had never had this happen anywhere before, wow! And here I'd  thought California had better sushi than Minnesota, in this particular case, definitely NOT.

Services was polite, but completely un-coordinated.  His ramen came out first, whereas I ended up waiting 25 minutes or more before my unagi-don finally came out...so we didn't get to eat together.

Due to the really bad food and bad service we didn't leave any tip.  The next thing you know, our waitress comes running after us to demand we tip her.  Talk about crazy! Last I heard tipping in the United States is an OPTION, not a requirement. THEY should be comping US for the gross food and bad service!  Such ludicrous and entitled people these days...
author: Siobhan W.

description: If you love flavorful sushi then look no further. This is your spot. Seared salmon and hamachi nigiri will leave you wanting more. I am also a huge fan of their fried rolls, yes, some people may say that cream cheese has no place in sushi but It's just so good. The chefs are always really nice and will make just about anything of you ask. I have been here around 20 times and will be returning again and again. This is my go to sushi spot.
author: Alex H.

description:
I was going to go to Isobune but since they're closed, I gave Tenroku another shot. I'm a fan again. Big, delicious cuts of sashimi and overall great sushi caused me to reconsider my negative review.

Below is my prior review from about a year ago:

In the past, I would have given this place more like 4 stars. The sushi is good with lots of selections. I often have to ask for the conventional cuts that I like, because the belt is full of more exotic items. The last time I went the service was bad. My wife and I were seated but never asked if we wanted to order drinks. Our tea cups were never refilled. When I left I took the bottle of sake I had ordered but only partly completed. I asked for a bag in which to take it and was told that they are not allowed to sell drinks for take out. I thought this was strange at the time and looked this up online. I found a California statute that explicitly allows for this. (Section 23396.5 of the Business and Professions Code).  So at this point, the service was not just lackadaisical but also annoying and ignorant.
author: Paul N.

description: Fun little place with semi decent sushi for semi decent prices. Boy is it quick to rack up the prices when all you need to do is grab a little plate off the conveyor! The staff is nice and always there to fill up your tea cup, very attentive.
author: Katie A.

description:
Incredible selection and great prices. 

The salmon belly is something I'd never encountered before, and now it is one of my favorites. The butterfish is great, and they do a great job with the ever-elusive otoro. 

Most seats are at the counter, so not a great place for intimate dining. The staff is attentive and eager to please; if you want something that isn't on the conveyor (or out of reach) the chefs will be happy to get it for you. 

The selection runs from the mundane to the exotic. Grab edamame as an appetizer, try American-style sushi rolls if that's your thing, and ask what that one is that you don't recognize...it may become a new favorite.
author: Dan H.

description:
Surprise is the word here. 

Rotating sushi ... probably stale... in the Japantown mall ... packed restaurant ... must be all tourists, eh?

The Yelp reviews pulled me in here, as this one is on upper end of the rating scale in Jtown. So maybe not a tourist trap after all?

Most certainly not. The sushi - well prepared, both traditional and creative. The sashimi - tasty and fresh off the boat. Service - fast and friendly. Prices - fair.

I'd definitely come back here. Great selection of fresh sushi without emptying your wallet. Top!
author: Sebastian F.

description:
Sushiiiiiiiiii!! Yum yum yum.

Friday evening no wait but it was a full house. I would say the plates are reasonably priced. There is a wide variety of cooked and raw sushi. Also on the conveyor belt are appetizers like edamame and oysters! Everything was beautifully presented and delicious. Service was great too. If you wanted a certain item that isn't on the belt, tell one of the guys and they'll make it for you. They also provide warm wet towels (oshibori) for wiping your hands before eating (never seen this done before).

Will definitely come back here for more sushi!
author: Benita M.

description: Tapeworm. Facial hair. Last time we went to this place there was a facial hair in our sushi and the server quickly said she was sorry and removed the order. We didn't make a big deal about it and continued to dine. This time however was the last straw, my wife pulled a raw piece of Halibut and thank goodness noticed there was a worm that was roughly 3 centimeters long. I'm not a worm expert but with raw fish all I can think of is it being something like a tapeworm. We stopped eating and told the sever saying this time we wanted to leave and said we are not paying. It's not something I usually do but we both now feel like vomiting and hope we don't have any issues with a parasite and need to go to the hospital. Before we left I told their staff they can not serve this to guest and I highly suggest they go over all over their fish to make sure it's ok. We're not going back, and I encourage everyone to dine here with caution..
author: S D.

description:
Wow what an amazing place 1st time visit to Japantown and was looking forward to this place and it did not disappoint. 

The Uni omg the Uni was what I always heard chefs on food network moan about. It doesn't taste bitter or salty like the ocean instead it tastes like a fresh egg bursting with umami. Make sure to get the individual ones not the one in the tray box.

We had the chance to sit near the sushi chef and we kept eying his creations and he churned out the good stuff. The fish the squid it's all sooooo good. Were definitely gonna come back when we get the chance.
author: Vincent G.

description: After reading the yelp reviews, I was pleasantly surprised at this place. I don't know that you're paying for the fish so much as the experience of watching stuff spin around, talk about what it is, what you like, if you're still hungry. I'm sure there are cheaper places to get equally as good sushi, but the sushi here is good and the place is cute.
author: Mary S.

description: This was really good sushi, I thought per plate price was reasonable. I know people mention their $1-2 sushi places, well this isn't that. I felt the fish was all fresh, service really good and not having ever done 'conveyor belt' sushi this was a very good experience. Don't go here if you don't know your fish, it's kind of a surprise each time you take a plate.
author: Lindsey G.

description:
False Advertising

They pull you in with their large TV flashing "Santa Barbara Uni Box $10!" And their professionally photos of sushi selection.

People love uni like it's some form of drug.  We sat down and order some fresh oysters and a box of uni.  The chef gave me that smirk laugh and said "We don't have uni tray but I can make you Uni  nigiri.  Now why would  I pay $10 for 2 pieces of uni when I can get a tray of 12 as advertised??

The look said it all: "Sucker!  We never have that!  It's just advertising".  I saw the fish selection and figure it would be down hill from here.  Old colorless fish.  Why gamble? 

Sorry I am a San Francisco native and not a desperate unwitted tourist.  There are much better authentic sushi shops all along Geary Street besides here.
author: Lance L.

description: Again a great little conveyor belt sushi place, where you pick your own sushi or even order over the counter.  This is our go to place whenever we are in Japan town.  Seems quality and staff are the same as out previous visit.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Was walking around Japantown with a friend trying to decide on a place to eat lunch when we walked by this place and I saw their advertisement out front of their store that said $10 for a whole tray of UNI.  I thought it was too good to be true so the first thing I did was ask the hostess about this deal.  After she confirmed it to be very true we decided to give this place a try.  

It's a conveyor belt sushi restaurant.  It's small and cozy.  You sit along side the conveyor belt like it's a bar and you take whatever sushi you like off the belt or you can order it thru the waitress or chef.  The plates on the conveyor belt are color coded to be a specific price.

So the first thing I order is obviously the tray of Uni.  It really was a whole tray of Uni for only $10 so I was adding Uni to everything.  I even added Uni to my udon and it was so delicious.  They set aside only a # of trays for the $10 deal so once it's out it won't be available until their next shipment.  The sushi was pretty good and their pricing is not bad at all.  

I still have doubts about all sushi restaurants that do this conveyor belt type of service.  I love the experience because it's cool and fun but I also can't get that thought out of my head about how long that sushi may have been rotating around on that belt with nothing to keep it refrigerated.  But I was very satisfied with the food and I had a great time here.  Will be coming back.
author: Jen C.

description: Waited for more than a half hour, and the waitress helped two white guys who just came and let them dine in before us. Poor customer service. Avoid it!
author: Jiarong W.

description:
It's fun if you've never had conveyer belt sushi and the service was friendly. In terms of quality this place is just okay. The fish did not taste too fresh since some of it had been sitting on the belt for awhile without being chilled. I'm not sure how often they switch it out.

The prices are actually pretty high and I felt like I spent too much money without even feeling full. Plates range from $2-$10 depending on the color but most of the good plates like salmon or eel over rice were about $5-6 each. That adds up quickly since each plate doesn't have much on it. The toro was 2 slices for $7 and the quality was mediocre.

Overall I probably wouldn't try this place again unless I wanted to show someone the novelty of conveyer belt sushi. The one plus is that you can start eating right away without waiting for your food. We spent about $55 total for 2 people and were still not full afterwards.
author: Linda X.

description: I have lunch here every week because I LOVE it. My favorite place in Japan Town. The seafood is FRESH and the chefs are friendly. I love coming here on my lunch break by myself or with friends.
author: M.E. T.

description:
I wanted to love this place. But there's just no way I could. 

Part of our party had the sushi, and the other had the tonkotsu ramen. The sushi was fine, but not great. We ordered our ramen nearly as soon as we sat down and asked 30 minutes later where it was. They said 5 minutes more. About 15 minutes later, it came out. Our suspicion was that they forgot. It would've been ok, or at least better, if it had been good ramen, but it wasn't. The tonkotsu, which I'm used to being pork belly, was breaded chicken in milky, flavorless broth. I had a piece of pork-chicken and no more. It was seriously the worst ramen I'd ever had. 

More so, the service was non-existent. Tracking waiters down to check on our food was a bummer. 

I definitely won't be coming back ever. 

The good: east to get a table at 8 PM on a Friday night. 
The bad: the food and the service.
author: Amanda B.

description: Decent sushi...Prices vary based on the type of color plate you choose, ranging from about $3 for basic sushi, up to $7 for fancier sushi. You can also order off a separate menu if the conveyer belt doesn't have enough enticing sushi variety. There are 3 pieces of sushi/plate. Pretty good if you're interested in sampling a wide variety of sushi and would be a fun restaurant environment to bring friends and family because of the quirky conveyer belt. You get to watch the chefs make the sushi, which is nice to see them using fresh ingredients right in front of you. Only reason why I rated 3 stars is because the sushi was just ok but I only had like, eh, 9 pieces for $16 (with tip)...so not much bang out of my buck in my opinion but still really cool experience! Service was also very friendly!
author: Amy T.

description:
Food (*** out of *****);  The sushi is good quality and it is made in a visually appealing manner. However, I'm not a fan of the sushi on a conveyer belt concept because the sushi is at ROOM TEMPERATURE. No, it doesn't smell fishy because they probably remove it from the conveyer belt after the lunch rush. However, I like my sushi chilled not at room temperature. If you like OK sushi at room temperature, then consider the food to be 4-5 stars. 

Atmosphere (**** out of *****); Very cramped and uncomfortable seating. There is no space to walk inside. I had a backpack on and it was very very dicey trying to navigate the restaurant without hitting anybody with my backpack. The seats are tiny wooden bar stool-like chairs. A/C was timid. The A/C should be ice cold if they have sushi out without refrigeration. 

Service (*** out of *****); Not bad service, but considering that this was very expensive sushi, it should've been more than essentially self-service cafeteria style. You grab the sushi off the conveyor belt and serve yourself. The waitress only serves you drinks. 

Conclusion (*** out of *****); Overpriced. I included a photo of the menu with prices for you to view. For OK sushi served at room temperature in a cute novel conveyor belt concept restaurant, dine at Tenroku Sushi.
author: Wai Y.

description: I just don't get this place. It's literally the only restaurant in SF where you can walk up to the entrance and have employee after employee walk within 2 feet of you...and completely ignore you. Not greeting, not eye contact, no "please wait". If this happened in Japan it would be a national emergency.
author: Nick C.

description: Roaming around Jtown and looking for lunch.  What drew me in was the picture of a $10 tray of uni.  Sat promptly,  tea appeared along with wasabi and ginger.  Started looking at the conveyor belt for my selection.  Decent selection and the blue fin tuna... So delicious!  Uni fresh,  the waitress recommended the salmon belly with ikura eggs on top.. O my it literally melted on my tongue!  Her next recommendation was the hamachi with monkfish liver,  it was quite delicious.  Great ambience, great service,  a little pricy but it was good. Definitely worth a try!
author: Alicia A.

description:
Really gross. The fish tasted like it has been sitting there the whole day (it got all slimy). Got like 2 things and bounced because the food made me want to gag. 

Avoid at all cost. Might save you a trip to the hospital.
author: Janet K.

description:
5/5 for location and pleasantly mesmerizing sushi conveyer belt

3/5 for food

Average 4/5

Not the greatest sushi (it's ok) but a fun place to eat. Good option for food before a show at the Fillmore.
author: Daniel N.

description: I guess it is no secret now if you read enough yelp review that the key to this place is to order the sushi from the chef right in front of you ! The shrimp head is special order but guess what ? IT IS A BLACK DISH ITEM !!!! The toro is good for me and the quality I guess depends , and for that price you cannot beat it !
author: Wai C.

description: Great fish, reasonable price, very friendly chefs and easy access. Yeah it has some bad reviews but I don't really understand why its that bad. Fish was pretty great and I would come here again.
author: Dennis N.

description:
Loved it, seated quickly and eating almost immediately

Solid mainstay items and a few surprises!: fried shrimp heads, thick cut sashimi, and rolls

Couldn't help but watch people's faces as they watched the conveyor belt, trying to decide what to eat
author: gina p.

description: Ok this isn't the best sushi but I really enjoyed it. First of all conveyer belt is cool which you get to pick your food through your eyes. I love the house special seared salmon belly, two big buttery pieces  of toro for $7 is a pretty good deal along with $10 for whole tray of descent uni and last their giant rolls are pretty good. Overall descent sushi for descent price. My go to place ! Oh and service is good from the sushi chef who I've seen worked there for years. The waitress service is hit or miss on who is working.
author: Christy V.

description:
Definately an awesome experience.

Note: This place is for something to try. Not very good with low budget and hungry people.
I mean 2x of tofu cost $2.5 and 2 slice of Raw Salmon cost $5.50

The only sushi I like is the Uni. No, I don't like it. I love it. Maybe because I loce sea urchin that made me love it no matter what. 

Ohhh, and yeah! The Ramen in here is a must!
author: Dan Asher D.

description: Favorite sushi place ever! I don't know what this notice is about "poor" food quality. I have eaten here plenty of times and have never gotten sick or felt funny after eating their food. This is a fun place to eat with the conveyer belt that brings sushi around! It's fun to watch the chefs cook also! I recommend this place to everyone. The cheesecake is amazing by the way. And don't be afraid to try new sushi you haven't before! I was scared to before coming to this place but now I like more sushi than I have before because their food looks so appetizing and tastes so good! It's pretty cheap too for another plus!
author: Brieann K.

description: Eh, just ok sushi. Fun concept but definitely a one time only kind of place. You can find much better sushi for the same or similar price point. It's what I would expect for Mall food. 3 people cost $200 all in for 30 dishes of 2 pieces of sushi, nigiri, shashimi or some combo of. I think you could spend the same at a better place and be more satisfied
author: Phillip T.

description:
So far, so good.

Trick of the trade?  Order your items fresh unless you see the sushi guys set new plates down on the conveyor belt.  I checked out the belt and found that it wasn't temperature regulated.  I was expecting some cold air or something...but nada.  A little skeptical about that...especially if an undesired item ends up sitting there for a few hours.  

Otherwise, the sushi was decent.  I wouldn't say the best I've ever had...but probably the best you will find in japantown.  The sushi choices are almost exactly the same as isobune but a heck of a lot better.  I swear that a couple of the guys that work there used to work at isobune also!  

The four of us ordered around 20 plates.  I would say that only 2 or 3 items were meh.  Prices ranged from a few bucks a plate to $10/plate.

The sushi guys working there had personality and were super friendly.  Until I'm given a reason not to come back, this will be my go to if I'm craving sushi in J-town.
author: Jen W.

description: This was fun! My first belt sushi experience. The oysters were melt-in-your-mouth delicious!!!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Customer services is the best! Being able to watch the chefs make sushi in front of you is pretty cool and honestly the pricing is just right for the quality. This place is not good for groups but rather for parties of 3 or less. I really enjoyed going here and trying all sorts of different seafood and sushi. Everything was fresh and delicious. There's also parking about a block down (if you're driving there).
author: Anu C.

description: I like the food here. I always go to this restaurant and became friends with one waitress. All chefs and waitress are very nice. Hahaha... This restaurant is always busy, and there is a lot on one plate. Lots of people. しかし、おんなあるじが好きじゃないですね。それにちょっと多い香料があるから、時々魚が新鮮かどうか分からないですね。I think the best round sushi place in San Francisco city.
author: Eva D.

description:
This is the most affordable for quality sushi place I've found since moving to the city. I could eat the salmon toro here all day long. It completely melts in my mouth and they are generous with the fish slices! Cost is $5.25 for two pieces, which is actually a really good deal. The otoro is $7 for two pieces, which is also really cheap.

I've brought friends here and they all love it. One of my friends commented that the Uni is here is really good for the price too and he ate several plates.

Overall if you're looking for a no frills budget friendly sushi place, definitely come here. Service is always friendly and usually the wait isn't too long.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Tenroku sushi has the greatest and most affordable sushi that you can find. Their uni has a nice and smooth texture that melts into yourop mouth it also has a very fresh salty taste, my only problem was the water cups were a little small so I kept running out and it took a little to get it filled again. Usually when you get tuna it is kind of rough and it separates while you chew it. At Tenroku it is as smooth as salmon is and has a nice soft texture. The o-toro is very good here and they sear it and put crunchy onions on top and give it a great sour taste. The wait is not too long and the seating is comfortable only a little bit squished. One of the disappointments was that  there was an advertisement for a tray of uni for $10 but they didn't have it for some unknown reason. The chefs and waitresses were nice and very diligent but the still took a little long. Overall I gave this a 5/5 because their sushi is the best I've ever had, the only downside was the cramped space while eating
 I would highly recommend eating here while in the San Francisco area it is sure to be a pleasing and satisfying experience.
author: Ryan F.

description:
As of right now this is my favorite sushi place in San Francisco ! 
The sushi is on a belt so you sit around it and grab what you like to eat. Each plate is color coded and there's a sign to tell you how much each one is. If you want something specific or some modifications on preference the sushi chefs are more than happy to help you . The service is excellent ! 
They use blue fin tuna and it's delicious ! The chopped up toro with pickled wasabi is my boyfriend's favorite while mine is the torched salmon with some toppings :) 
These are not always seen on the belt so keep an eye out for them if you see them making it. Be careful how many plates you grab though , it's so yummy that you don't realize you racked up quite a bill XD 
Def recommend !
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Rating: 3.5 stars

We were planning to go to Udon Mugizo but the line was cray, so we decided on Tenroku since it was right across the way (and no wait!).

So food. The sushi here isn't bad and the fish are pretty fresh for a sushi boat place. It is pricey compared to Sakana Bune on Geary, but normal compared to a traditional sit-down restaurant. The plates range from $2.25 to $10 for the special items; most plates were in the $5 range. I think the blue fin nigiri was $5 (2 pcs). They also have ramen, udon and donburi on their menu but didn't really take a look at that. The bill for 2 came out to be $55 before tip -- I don't think we had more than 10 dishes total? =X I will confess that I did grab a $7 plate teehee

The overall selection is pretty good considering they put uni and amaebi right on the belt. They also had some interesting nigiri on the belt -- one looked to be seared salmon topped with roe and uni. Outside of nigiri, they have the basic rolls like Cali rolls topped with assorted fish, spicy tuna rolls, rolls topped with imitation crab, etc. Lots of baked rolls, FYI for those who like those!

Bonus point for me was when I saw that they actually put wasabi under the pieces of fish!

The staff are super friendly, clear away your lids quickly and refill empty water cups right on time. 

I liked that Tenroku's nigiri is more "authentic" than other sushi boat spots and the fish is quite fresh, but I wasn't extremely blown away by what they offered.
author: Doris K.

description:
I was ready to get snarky about this Japan Center place and probably go through the whole "I Love Lucy" scene with Lucy and Ethel at the chocolate factory ("Speed it up, Otto!") . But I have to admit I was pleasantly surprised at Tenroku and how efficiently this kaiten-zushi worked. 'Kaiten' refers to a conveyor belt operation which I much prefer over the more Disneyland-derived sushi boat concept where subpar places like Sushi Umi on Bush attract bothersome gnats to their artificial waterways. First of all, I like the see-through plastic lids they use over each small plate that comes by (photo: http://bit.ly/1MJ2YRJ). They accommodate the germophobe in all of us (or frankly should be in all of us), and of course like the boat flotillas, the plates come in eight different colors to indicate the prices which range from $2 to $6.

They also have a big off-the-belt menu, too, and I took advantage by ordering the $6 Ankimo 'cause I loves me some monkfish liver (photo: http://bit.ly/1D3AQmV). Crowned with a bit of tobiko, the three slices were deliciously bathed in a little lime juice. Then it was off to the belt or maybe off with the belt considering how much I was eating. I tried to come up with a game plan so I wouldn't stuff myself before my stomach knew it, but alas the road to hell is paved with good intentions, don't y'know? I started in the middle with a green plate that intrigued me as it rounded toward me the second time. It was the $4 City Roll, quite an elaborate creation for the price with avocado and eel wrapped in rice and then topped with crab salad, maguro, tobiko, green onion and a mayo sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/1ED8aRD).

A simpler dish was in order after that, and the $3.50 Saba (Mackeral) Nigiri did the trick (photo: http://bit.ly/1LrGEdZ). Pretty fresh. The $4.50 Fresh Oysters made for a nice switch-up at that point in my marine life consumption (photo: http://bit.ly/1MJ2R8J). I was figuring outby this point it was best to grab the last thing the chef made and put on the belt between special orders. You have to keep an eagle eye on the guy across from me who was following a similar tactic. That's how I lost my Hamaichi Nigiri. Bastard. But I did manage to grab the $4.50 Tai (Red Snapper) Nigiri with a little fish roe on top (photo: http://bit.ly/1ED8cJh). OK, I need to stop. In the meantime, a couple of German tourists had come in, saddled next to me, and copied everything I ate. I was ready to get all Cookie on them, but then the guy said, "You have good taste." Damn straight.

FOOD - 4 stars...surprisingly good sushi spot considering it comes around on a conveyor belt..."Speed it up, Otto!"
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...clean, a bit cramped, especially when they try to seat people together to facilitate the chef
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...attentive, maybe a tad too much
TOTAL - 4 stars...I won't make fun of kaiten operations again...at least not much
author: Ed U.

description: This place was so bad, I had to argue my way out of not paying for a shitty bowl of ramen. The owner kept arguing that her ramen is good and everyone buys her ramen, so I told her , good for you but I didn't like it and I would love to return it and she automatically denied my request and told me to pay for it. I tried to walk out from the place , but she called security on us. I told the owner I was gonna pay for what I had ate for and not the ramen and she yelled at me and told me fuck you and flipped me off. What a good customer service she had, this place is so horrible , if I say DONT BUY THE RAMEN, DONT BUY THE RAMEN. FFOOD POISONING
author: Lori K.

description:
LOVED this place! We came on a friday night and waited about 20 min for a seat but it was well worth it! 
We were served hot tea and given a warm cloth to clean our hands. The sushi selection was awesome! I was able to place any special requests right with the sushi chefs, and then they just handed me my orders. Everything was delicious! The prices are also very reasonable and all the plates are colored by price.
Such a great date night! We will be back!
author: Larissa S.

description:
My favorite conveyor belt spot in the Bay thus far.

Good variety of Nijiya market fish quality at a great value + delicious cucumber wrapped mango lobster roll. I have no idea why people go to shitty Isobune in the same plaza when the quality and value at Tenroku is 800x better.''

They do need to differentiate their black plates better though. Solid black is the cheapest at and embroidered black is the most expensive. With so many colors in front me, I got a black-plated scallops dish and was like omgz I'm like a shrewd farmers' market azn grandma so good at picking out value until I realized I actually picked the expensive black plate.
author: Tian Q.
