description: I got food poisoning from eating here. Beware of eating anything here! I don't understand how people still come here when the quality is so poor. That's the problem with conveyor belt sushi. You can't guarantee that it's fresh. Go elsewhere if you want to get sushi, plenty of other places to go in Japan town
author: Esther D.

description:
I have never really been a fan of "carousel" sushi - can be a bit like playing Russian Roulette in my opinion, but the service was way better, the fish was much fresher, and the price was more affordable than ever expected. Tenroku Sushi is a fantastic place to stop in anytime to get a good, fast meal when in Japantown. 

Conveniently located in one of the two indoor shopping buildings, the uber casual atmosphere of TS comes with some really nice unexpected touches. After choosing my seat at the bar, I was quickly greeted by a staff member and provided an oshibori (warm, damp cloth to wash with prior to eating, as is custom in Japan) and a steaming hot cup of soothing, complimentary Green Tea. Great first impression!

Then, decision making time. All of the sushi and various offerings pass by on small, different colored plates covered with a clear dome. The color of the plate represents how much that particular plate costs. You can also order directly from the sushi chef if you wish, but I found no need. 

Tried basic Cali Roll, Fried Shrimp Heads, Marinated Cucumber with Fish Sauce, Shrimp Tempura, Tuna, a Combo of Asst Fish that included Salmon. All very good.  

Overall: Tenroku Sushi is a wonderful place to take a short break from all of the Japantown fun and get a good, fast, light meal at an adorable price! Under $30 for two in San Francisco, and the hubby had a beer...wow! Recommend. Domo arigato!
author: Dawn H.

description: Sushi was great and fresh! I just love sushi on a conveyor belt. Great price as well and friendly service. Definitely recommend this place!
author: Carol N.

description:
It's conveyor belt sushi, novel if you've never seen it before. Kaiten sushi can be done well if it's fresh and a restaurant has a high turnover rate but for some reason this location within Japantown which has a ton of tourists; still manages to keep stale, non fresh sushi on the belts.

If you want the more fresh fish, ask for a specific order. I thought the hamachi was okay and the salmon was eatable. I'm nowhere close to a sushi snob, perhaps a bit spoiled after living near the Torrance and Costa Mesa Japanese communities with fairly priced fresh sushi.

On second thought, it's a bit depressing eating in here unless you're in a pinch. Also, it's not even that cheap for kaiten sushi.
author: Steven C.

description:
MY NEW GO TO SPOT FOR SUSHI IN SF!!! 
so fresh, they are not stingy with the amount of fish and stuff they put in sushi, they even put LOTS of avocado. 
all the sushi is so fresh!!! 
the environment was cool, supper fast paced(but cool) it was like a modern spot, i loved it so much. 
HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. 
you won't be disappointed!!!!!!!!!
author: Annie C.

description:
My 12 years old daughter and her classmates stopped at this place today while on their field trip. There was an empty plate next to my daughter's seat that she didn't eat from, and the staff made her pay for it. 
It happened so that there was a couple seated just on the other side from that empty seat, and yet, they put a blame on a child. 
What was supposed to be a fun adventure at the end of the school year, turned into a stressful and tearful experience. 
It's shameful to take advantage of children!
I am not even sure if they can legally let children eat at their place without guardian supervision.
author: Inga L.

description:
I looove sushi, so naturally when I was recently in SF visiting my sister, I suggested we get sushi for dinner. Her and her bf brought me here! First of all, the mall it's in is crazy! Everything is Japanese and it is very COOL! It was very fun (and different, for me) to see so many Japanese stores, legit bookstores and whatnot all with Japanese books, stuff, etc. I imagine it's just like it is in Japan! 

ANYWAY, though, I digress!! 

Tenroku! It was very tasty! I looove conveyer belt sushi, seems so fun! I always get very excited! Although I must admit, my crazy brain will start doing the math of adding every little plate I take, ha, so I sort of have to forget about that and just take what I want! And I did here! I grabbed salmon, rolls that looked interesting, and my fave, spicy scallop roll! I seemed to get the only one coming around because we couldn't find another! My sister had a little try of mine and wanted some of her own. So I asked the chef if he could make me some more and sure enough, he did! Very nice people working here and the sushi was quite tasty! Cute little spot in this Japanese mall!
author: Ally T.

description: The high quality of the salmon and blue fun tuna blew me away. The cuts were incredibly beautiful and the taste was excellent. I only had a few of the rolls, and they were average to above. Obviously the trick with sushi boat is to go when it's busy so the dishes turn over more quickly and you get more choices.
author: Hope M.

description:
When I first heard that a kaiten zushi joint had (finally) opened up in SF, I knew I had to come here to check things out.  Although I'd like to say I'm not sure why, I actually know exactly why - I can be a sucker for gimmicks.  So, despite already knowing what to expect of the food (mediocre, at best), I still had to experience Tenroku for myself!

If you're not familiar with kaiten zushi joints, they're essentially the same as sushi boat restaurants, but with a conveyor belt instead of boats.  Thus, if you've been to a sushi boat restaurant, you've essentially been here as well (did I mention I can be a sucker for gimmicks?).  However, compared against Isobune (Japantown's sushi boat joint), Tenroku ranks a little better.

Prices between the two are pretty comparable and while the variety at both is decent enough (if you want something that's not already circulating, you can order from one of the "chefs"), I really like how the dishes at Tenroku are covered as they circle around.  Though I'm not nearly as neurotic as Monica on Friends about cleanliness, I certainly appreciate how it lessens the chances of potential for flies landing on the food or people breathing/coughing/sneezing on it.

As far as quality goes, it's fine as long as you don't have high expectations.  Rolls are no better or worse than your average, Chinese owned sushi joint, but sashimi can be hit or miss.  The sake/salmon sashimi I grabbed was decent, but the hamachi nigiri had an odd color and not a lot of flavor.  Either way, it might be best to order sashimi from the "chef" instead so it's a little fresher (who knows how long they circle sometimes).

Although service here is pretty good, places like this simply can't compete with more traditional restaurants if you're looking for some legitimate sushi/sashimi.  However, if you're looking to try a kaiten zushi/sushi boat joint, Tenroku isn't a bad bet and better (for the most part) than nearby Isobune.
author: Mike L.

description:
+/- THE FOOD
3.5 stars. The food here was just okay. They didn't have a huge variety of sushi and we kept on watching the rotating belt spit out the same type of sushi over and over again. Some of my favorites were the uni roll, scallop roll, and seared salmon roll. A lot of the non-nigiri rolls were not that special. The fish wasn't super fresh either. The restaurant was pretty small so it's hard to seat larger groups, I thought it was a little expensive as we spent about $70 for 2 people. However, we got pretty full after about 5-6 plates each person.
author: Cindy C.

description: There's a reason why this place always have a line. Quality of sashimi are great for what they charge. Very reasonably priced for an establishment within Japantown. This is one of the few I would recommend.
author: Aaron K.

description:
Wow, I and my special guest birthday boy loved Tenroku, as compared to the other -subpar- -disappointing- sushi boat joint in Japan Town: Isobune, from whence we just came after a short and disappointing visit:

http://www.yelp.com/biz/isobune-sushi-san-francisco-3?utm_campaign=www_business_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct)

@ Tenroku the waitresses were super polite, nice and attentive. The Tenroku sushi "chefs" were super nice and smiling. The dishes were a tasty, fresh and diverse representation of small plates Cooked goodies, Vegi options, Sashimi and SUSHI. Nice portions as well. 

@ Tenroku each plate covered with a small plastic lid. Protecting against the transfer whatever the other folks peering, picking (but hopefully not sneezing or coughing on) as the plates zoom by. This is a GREAT serving feature, but creates double the dish handling task servers need to perform. Tenroku is correct about the value of the feature being worth the added task, of dealing with the lids, which is transparent to the plate grabbers since the service people are tremendously attentive. I'm not a paranoid germophobe but admit a thought arises when open food is moving by XX number of people that just wandered in off the street that are sitting within inches of the food I am about to put in my mouth. I love humanity, its people I can't stand. 

Had maybe more than a dozen dishes, great quality, and some with surprisingly good portions (the salmon Sashimi was 2 generous chunks), all were GOOD. Since I didn't analyze the prices of the different colored plates; and can't comment on any price as compared to other sushi boat / conveyor joints (admittedly a limited amount of experience).  IF there is a price difference it would be completely worth it, the value meter is in the "good" zone.  

GO TENROKU !
author: Matsuo U.

description: Fish is in poor quality(the salmon on the belt surrounding was black...)Still this restaurant catches attention from tourists. A loooooong line at a Wednesday night waiting outside. Ridiculous!!!
author: Mandy W.

description:
FOOD
-fresh fish and shrimp
-good creative sushi
-not too much rice, with a little kick of wasabi inside

SERVICE
-sweet and nice

PRICE
-many option and reasonable 
-me and my boyfriend fill up our stomach for $70 

Will definitely come back again :)
author: Sunny L.

description:
A bit pricey for the higher end plates ($7), which include plates with uni and fatty tuna.

Fish quality was okay. I mean you can tell the regular tuna looked unnaturally red but I find that at a lot of regular Japanese restaurants too. The only special nigiri I ate was seared salmon topped ankimo and ikura; that was buttery good.

If you're looking to not get too stuffed, there are plates that have thick slabs of sashimi. That seemed to be very popular. If you are looking to get stuffed, they have plates with some funny looking rolls that are quite saucy.

We sat right by one of the "chefs" and every time he saw me eyeing something he was making, he would ask us if we wanted it. I appreciated his attentiveness.

Warakubune Sushi in the Castro is still my favorite place for conveyor belt sushi.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Surprisingly, I really enjoyed this place! There was no wait on a Sunday afternoon and because everything you need is on a conveyer belt, you can get in and out of there very quickly. 

There's no temperature regulation on the sushi going around (room temp) and if you look closely enough, you can see the same plate making a few rounds. However, the more popular dishes are usually always being taken off, so you don't have to worry about it being out for too long. Also, if you observe what the sushi chef's are making, you can see what they put out and you'll know what's freshly made. 

My favorite are the nigiris- salmon, hamachi belly, toro, and uni!

For the amount and quality, I think this place is a great deal! If you're in the area and looking for a quick, relatively afforadable sushi place, I would recommend coming here!

Also, if your kids like nigiri- they do put wasabi in there, so be careful!

The customer service is very friendly, you're greeted with hot tea, ginger, and wasabi. I'll be back if I'm around japantown!
author: Letty H.

description:
I say this place is ok to me. The sushi was not bad and it's moderately priced for where it is located. There's also another place in the building that has conveyor belt sushi. However, my friends say this place is better.

I had this roll which I do not know the name. It had eel sauce, mayonaise, fish eggs, avocado, the whole shabang! It was delicious. :) I took a picture of it.

Fish was fresh too!
author: Kay T.

description:
It is what it is. If it's rotating sushi, I don't expect it to be the tippity toppest quality. However, I do expect the be able to grab and eat from a decently varied selection as soon as I sit down. In that regard, Tenroku serves. I've gone in a few times during lunch, and there is always a decent variety of nigiri and crazy Americanized fusion rolls going around.

The quality is surprisingly for "fast food" sushi. The rice has a delicious, not too overpowering mirin (rice vinegar) flavor. I LOVE THE $10 for an uni boat deal. What a steal for a restaurant! The fish has always been acceptably fresh, although not anything to write home about. I usually go for simple nigiri rather than rolls, and here, they're quite good, especially considering you can get them on order here (service has been extremely fast for me), with a better-than-average price-to-quality ratio.

I do love the fact that this is one of the few (maybe only?) actual rotating sushi restaurants with a CONVEYOR BELT in the Bay Area. That is, not a boat. That's pretty legit, as far as Japanese sushi goes. While I'm reserving my judgment for Blue C Sushi to open, at the moment, Tenroku is the best rotating sushi restaurant I've been to in San Francisco.
author: Jade V.

description:
A fun fact about conveyor belt sushi is that necessarily, the majority of the sushi on the conveyor belt is undesirable: the desirable plates get picked up, and the undesirable ones are left over to go circling around the room for hours. 

As such, most of the plates I ended up trying (and I really did try to pick the fresh/good ones) were quite mediocre, as well as quite small. New plates hit the conveyor belt at a snail's pace: the kitchen was clearly critically understaffed.

I suppose a good thing is that it was rather inexpensive -- though for the quality of the experience still definitely overpriced.
author: John L.

description:
Amazing sushi for ridiculously amazing prices! I've had sushi from both Socal and NorCal and a place like this I would assume poor fish quality, but man was I wrong. I got some Otoro and tasted just as great as other restaurants that charge 16 to 18 dollars! This place is a must try. I actually came to dine in for the conveyor belt experience and I am glad I came in.

 Don't know why this place isn't at least 4 stars. The service was nice and they took our order when we didn't see something we wanted. 

If you haven't gone to a place like this they charge by the color of the plate
author: Oscar L.

description: Have come here now twice so I feel I can write about it. I love the conveyer belt sushi concept: you sit, you see, you grab, you eat. The quality per value ratio is just ok though: you know you're sacrificing quality for price, but I feel I can get better quality somewhere else for the price, and be served. Ups: fast lunch during a work day, food was good for a conveyer belt place, staff was attentive and nice, wide variety of sushi choices, you can eat as low as $2.50 per plate. Downs: most of you like costs as much as other normal sushi restaurants $4.5 - $6 per plate, sushi is not chilled, very cramped place and no ambiance whatever
author: Massimo M.

description:
The best selection on a rotating sushi bar I've ever seen, and FRESH, they were making and dumping new stuff on there the whole time and this was a
Ho-hum Monday lunch crowd. We ate til stuffed, 10 plates and misos for $50, including the $8 Kobe beef which despite prior reviews was not worth it to us.
author: b p.

description:
Really just 3.5 but I rounded up not down.
For a sushi train place it is not bad, but its nothing that special either.
If you need sushi and you are on a time budget, it works quite well.
Thats also assuming there is no line to get in, which is not true at busy times.
author: David T.

description:
I came in with no expectations. Kaiten zushi in San Francisco!? Usually a miss. Tenroku is definitely Cantonese pseu-shi. It is owned and run by the folks who do Sushi Raw. 

For the sushi purists who read my reviews, this is not the place for you. 

This is a good spot for those in betweeners or those nights where you want a mix. 
Yes, there are jive a$$ rolls on the menu. Yes, they serve jive a$$ sushi. For example my favorite was this little plate with 3 pieces on it. It was half of a roll that was basically a California roll with seared albacore and jalapeno on top.  Definitely a step up from Isobune (which isn't saying much but hey..)

Still, the fish is fresh, cuts are nice, and the price is right.
author: Susy C.

description: Slow service, didn't get my edamame within the 30 minutes I was there so I ended up canceling it. Tamago was okay, very little rice. Spicy tuna roll was okay as well. When seated they automatically brought my parents hot tea and me water. They didn't ask what we wanted, my dad and I wanted hot tea so it worked out as I just switched with my mom. You would have to ask for all waters later if you want water.
author: Lexi H.

description: Really really blah sushi. Tempura had no flavor at all, and the fish didn't taste fresh or flavorful. I would definitely not be back. The restaurant also smelled. And the selection of sushi was the most boring and bland that I've seen in a while.
author: Koshika S.

description:
Fish is fresh, and very good quality even though it's priced low. The waitresses are very attentive - my sister dropped her tissue on the ground and was about to pick it up, but the waitress noticed and picked it up and gave a new piece of tissue.

Much better than isobune (the other boat sushi conveyor belt place in japantown) in terms of quality, taste and standard.

My favorite is the seared salmon belly with toro and ikura!
author: Jane W.

description: came here last night, and since it was my second visit, i knew what to get versus not get! hence everything was pretty delicious..and really reasonably priced. solid spot - this will become a regular for me i hope!
author: Christina L.

description: Super fresh sushi, friendly service, fast, and convenient. Front row seats of generous sushi making.     The sushi tastes even better than they look. There are also hooks under the table to put your bags and purses!
author: Michael C.

description:
Nice new place in Japan Center on 2nd floor of restaurant row/East mall.  Very friendly servers and chefs - hot tea complimentary and tea and water were constantly refilled.  I could not believe I ran into someone I knew who ended up sitting next to me at the bar - both of us in town from Nevada.

We saw Tenroku on the way to Sophie's Crepes, and it was a "second dinner" after Sushiritto.  I loved the blue fin tuna sashimi, which seemed like chu-toro fatty deliciousness and had 2 of those - but we also got o-toro nigiri for $6.  Eric R. liked the salmon.  We also got saba, whole scallop, and hamachi.  Average plate cost $3.50 - no uni because of the weather in SB.  The turnover is quick because it is an in and out joint and fresh sushi was put on the conveyor belt based on customer interest.  When I ordered something from the chef in front of me, he would make 3 additional plates of it and add it to the belt.  I do not quite understand the tables outside of the place in the mall because there is no kaiten experience there.  I would return!!!
author: Lisa R.

description: Got seated right away, friendly waitress, very good price and fresh sushis !! What else :-)
author: Robert T.

description: Worst sushi ever... I havent had bad sushi were i got sick off of it with in hours... So i ate two eel nigiri and spicey tuna rolls... The eel here was truely horrible fatty piece ome i wasnt edible at all.. And i think the tuna here wasnt fresh.... Go to safeway for safer sushi....
author: Seaera T.

description:
I'm a sucker for sushi on a conveyor belt, so when I found out about this place, it was like I had gone to sushi heaven.

Tenroku is located in the West building in Japantown on the upper level past restaurant row. Like the majority of the restaurants there, it's a small and cozy place with very limited seating. We were lucky and didn't have to wait for a table, but the place is definitely worth waiting for. 

The waitresses were friendly, accommodating, and came by frequently without being overbearing. They passed out menus, but we opted to just get our sushi by taking plates from the conveyor belt. Taped to the table is a diagram that shows the price for each colored plate, which is super handy. Prices are...well, "Bay Area pricing", and our meal averaged $4.25/plate. It's reasonable, and I justify the price by the fact that I was able to sample a variety of different sushi. 

The sushi itself was so tasty! My favorites were the octopus and the one with salmon and a lemon slice on top. 

Oh! The sushi chefs also deserve a shout-out. The masterminds behind the counter are super nice and will make your sushi upon request if you don't see the one that you want on the belt. Now that's customer service : )
author: Sherry C.

description:
I'm not a fan of conveyor belt sushi restaurant. However, my friend, the birthday girl wanted to try it so I said "ok, let's do it!"  My reservation of sushi boats: there might be u fresh fish floating around and I get sick off it.

Overall, not a bad place. Staff's nice and the place is clean. Like robots, The chefs kept the belt filled consistently and quickly.  The staff kept our cups tall with tea and took away trays promptly. And the place has decent range of sushi/nigri for your heart's content.

As long as you don't expect high degree of creativity, the food and quality is pretty alright for a sushi boat style restaurant accompanied by a jolly time.
author: May W.

description:
Tried out the pretty new Tenroku in SF J-Town.  It's a conveyor belt sushi bar kinda place with chairs all around the bar & 1 table inside, some tables outside.

Got seated right away & just picked the dishes we wanted & we are eating!

There's face towels before you start.  Hot tea given.  Wasabi & ginger given to you almost as soon as you are seated.  All Chinese workers - chefs & wait staff.

Dishes we got.  No names given, so what I think they are:

ikura nigiri 
Some fancy looking roll
White tuna looking thing
Uni nigiri
Chopped up tuna looking thing
Unagi
hamachi w/ monkfish liver
scallop nigiri
fatty tuna looking nigiri
another of the fancy looking roll

lids put aside and wait person will pick up.

Prices are by plates which you stack up:
Blue $6
Yellow $3.5
Green $4
Purple $4.5
Red $5.5
Other plates from $3-$12

Our total before tip $48.40 for 2 ppl.  Charge it.
author: Ann L.

description: Really good sushi for the price point. It's obviously a no frills restaurant, but the value is great and I was impressed with the quality of the food. The chefs were really nice and were willing to quickly make us rolls on request. This was by far the best conveyor belt sushi restaurant I've been to. The conveyor belt was consistently full of sushi and other dishes. More importantly, there was a lot of good variety. All in all, a very enjoyable experience.
author: Stephan S.

description:
It's a kaiten-sushi. The overall price is more than isobune, but the quality of both craftsmanship and ingredients are here at a far higher level. 
It was Sunday mid afternoon, and I had very proper amaebi, uni, hamachi, salmon, ikura. There was also toro available. 
Ideal spot for either a snack or a good meal "ready to eat". 
12 plates $70.
author: Bruno S.

description: It's conveyor belt sushi, but even so the fish was of good quality and still tasted fresh.  Prices seemed like a great deal and it was great to see the sushi chefs work with smiles on their faces.
author: Margaret B.

description: Decided to finally give this place a try with my girlfriend Saturday evening. Sushi on display wasn't that great so I ordered a butterfish nigri from the sushi chef and it was not edible. The butterfish tasted fishy and it was still frozen! Service was slow. Friend and I was unsatisfied and still hungry so we paid our bill and left and ate next door. There are better sushi spots in the area than tenroku...Don't think we'll be back!
author: Joyce C.

description:
There were lots of "Lost in Translation" going on. The poor waitress, we told her about getting rice and Ikura eggs on the side (separated), so the kids can dig in with spoons. Not once, or twice, three times, but the FOURTH, she finally got it right. 

We couldn't help but laugh about it really. 

1st attempt: 
She brought two pieces of Ikura Nigiri wrapped in seaweed but had Ikura eggs with the quail eggs on top on the side. 
NOPE. Not correct. REDO. 
(On the house)

2nd attempt: 
Two quail eggs on separate serving spoons and no Ikura. 
NOPE. Not correct. REDO.
(On the house)

3rd attempt: 
Two Nigiri wrapped with Ikura eggs on serving spoons on the side. 
NOPE. Not correct. REDO.

4th attempt: 
Rice on the side. YES.
Ikura eggs on the side. YES.

Not only did all of this miscommunication happen, we also got old nigiri. My husband didn't want to get a new one since all of the mishaps with the Ikura happening.  But I did tell the hostess about the bad fish. Of course, she just responded by saying, "she doesn't know." Then one of the chef's walked by and told me all the fish is cut new every day. 

I was thinking, you might cut it new every day, but it doesn't mean it is fresh. We certainly won't be coming here next time. The one thing that we both said to ourselves is, "IT REALLY SUCKS TO PAY PREMIUM FOR BAD SUSHI." We'll try not to make this mistake again.
author: Moua L.

description:
We were on our wedding anniversary trip about 10 days ago and, while staying in Japantown, we checked this place out on our first night after reading about it on Yelp.
Our experience was SO GREAT that we came back for the next 3 dinners!!!
Kudos to Miguel for remembering how much I loved the Baby Octopus without even saying anything!!!
All of the different choices we made were a hit: fresh and yummy.
I even tried the sea snail that I normally would have been too squeamish to try and it was good.
I like the conveyor belt and how quickly the chefs replenish the empty spots.
Service was also great (except 1 night when maybe the waitress was having an off day).
We are definitely coming back on our next trip for more of the delicious sushi options they have!
A++++++ in my book: THANK YOU for making our trip even more fantastic!
author: Cri-Cri P.

description:
I'm always happy to have a meal here.  I'm not a sushi expert, but they have a wide variety of rolls and everything I have tried, I have enjoyed.  

The food is fresh, the service is pleasant, and the prices are reasonable.
author: Emily B.

description: Very good sushi place in Japan town. Enjoyed the sea urchin special selection very much.
author: Liu X.

description:
This is a fun little place in Japan town that serves small sushi plates on a metal conveyor belt. The plates are color coded by price and covered with a plastic lid. It's pretty tricky to pick them up one handed so I would use two just to be safe!

Overall the sushi was pretty good. I spent a lot of money because I have expensive taste and wanted things like uni nigiri. They had a deal where they put out a whole tray of uni for $10 which is pretty legit. Having lived 4 years somewhere where uni is hard to find, it was a must have. 

The tea came out super hot and I burnt my tongue so don't be a fool like me. 

I think the rice to fish ratio was overall good except for the scallop nigiri which had way too much rice! 

People were eating up the oysters left and right but I didn't get a chance to try it. Next time, tenroku!!
author: Patrick T.

description:
I came here because my sister in law who was visiting wanted sushi instead of ramen, and not being from the area, I jumped into the first place I could find with a rotating sushi belt.

 This place is cute and small as most shops in the Japan town mall are. You can order or just go to the conveyor belt and pick up the sushi you want, which is priced by whatever colored plate they are sitting on. In the end you total up the plates and pay.

I picked plates off the belt I knew I would like, mostly nigiri. I wasn't disappointed with the quality, and the price was expected. 

I'd say if you are walking by and feel like grabbing some sushi, this is a safe place to go. Nothing really unique about the sushi otherwise.
author: Annie L.

description: Based on my return visits, I still like this place a lot.  The sushi is fresh and service is very good. They have a large selection of sushi. You can ask the sushi chef to make something for you in case you do not see anything you want.
author: Hiroshi K.

description: Food-safety warnings be damned - I found the sashimi and basic rolls here to be fresh, affordable and delicious. Maybe this place is inconsistent for others but I will definitely return.
author: Liam S.

description: This place is small and nice. We went around 9pm so the place is quiet. We ordered 2 portions of salmon belly, 1 salmon sashimi (which they cut too thick) and 1 sushi each person. I think it costs around $20 pp, so its not bad. The salmon tastes fresh and the colour is nice, so I think its worth it to come here again
author: Joan T.

description:
Just left there. Still amazed at the indifferent customer service.
I was there with two of my kids, first visit, and we were enjoying the OK sushi. Then a waitress asked if we wanted more tea. She warned my son that it was very hot, and as she held (and filled) his cup with tea, the cup shattered and the ultra hot water spilled all over his leg, soaking his jeans. The pieces of the cup fell to the floor, and he raced to the bathroom to check his leg (red and uncomfortable, but thankfully not burned). They didn't really apologize; just brought us our bill when we asked. Never going back. Watch out for the tea.
author: Iconic S.

description:
Love the Sunset roll and ebi mayo
Yummy crab salad 
Fresh sashimi

I came in around 11:30 today and all the sushi was very fresh.  

Good service as well.  They always ask me if I need more tea and if there anything I want to eat.
author: Es L.

description:
My first time at a conveyor belt sushi bar -- very fun experience! 

It was surprisingly exciting to take the plates off the belt and to watch sushi/rolls I haven't seen before go by. 

Definitely recommend for sushi lovers. The fish was fresh and the sushi chefs and waiters were friendly.
author: Ana N.

description:
One of my favorite hidden gems in the city for sushi. Staff is friendly, fish is super fresh, everything is tasty! I highly recommend this place!

All the sushi chefs are great too.
author: Ivan C.

description:
I've been here three times now and I love this place! It's so much fun because it's like eating + shopping at the same time -- two of my favorite activities. I came here with low expectations (1. it's in touristy Japantown, and 2. it's conveyor belt sushi) but was pleasantly surprised by the quality and the variety. 

The salmon is heavenly -- super fresh. I was surprised at the generous cuts, and that the sashimi is the same price as the nigiri. Hamachi, albacore, and scallop were all great. I tried two unique things that were really yummy: 1) the saba topped with ankimo and 2) herring with capelin roe. Loved the ankimo (if you love liver, you will love this), and loved the layer of crunchy eggs with the herring. They even had oysters, and they were good too. The $6 toro isn't the heavenly amazing toro you'd get elsewhere, but it's pretty good. The walu was good the first time, but stringy the second. The uni wasn't the best quality, I would skip it. Skip the tempura, the flour is too thick and chewy. Even though it's on the menu, they didn't have trout either time I came here.

If you plan on making a reservation here, don't count on them honoring it. Once I made a reservation for 4 at 7 PM on the phone, arrived at the restaurant, and the waitress laughed, said I was late, and told me she gave my spot away. I looked down at my phone, and it was exactly 7:00. Another time I actually made a reservation in person, told them I would come back at 6:30, and they still didn't have a spot open for me when I came back. Luckily, this shouldn't be too big an issue since it's almost like fast food and there's lots of seat turnover, but just FYI if you're trying to catch a movie or something. 

The plates are color-coded for price, and you can easily order anything you don't see on the conveyer belt. The seating can be a little tight, but you usually don't have to wait!
author: Cynthia W.

description: Some of the best sushi I have had to date. If you are in Japan-town are looking for good quality sushi for a decent price look no further. Some of the reviews recently fail to realize pricing on conveyor sushi, you are getting 2-4 pieces of good quality fish and the higher the quality, or the uniqueness of the dish the pricing is obviously going to be higher. My girlfriend and I came her because we were dissatisfied too many times with the conveyor sushi on the other side of the mall and wanted a better quality of fish. Whenever we think about getting sushi I always suggest coming here, despite the 30 minute drive. The wait staff can yes sometimes be a little hard to get a hold of, but when you can manage to stop them, they are attentive and helpful, and ALWAYS keeping busy. Looking very forward to coming here again this weekend. Side note: definitely go for the otoro and/or the seared kobe beef, you will NOT regret it.
author: Connor W.

description: Super fun and friendly service!  Lots of variety of fresh selections and some interesting fusion creations that you gotta try, like a deep fried jalapeno roll (fish stuffed into a jalapeno and drop fried in tempura batter, then sliced).  Can't beat the $7 toro nigiri (2 pcs).  Ask for Miguel...he's the best!
author: Peter M.

description:
value oriented mexican sushi 

B+ quality of sushi at low cost

$7 for two piece Chūtoro (中とろ) middle cuts of bluefin tuna. Let me know if you can find something cheaper. I've tasted fancier places but double this price and half the fish.
author: Bunny C.

description:
It's a sushi bar so don't have excessively high expectations. Quality is good and the prices are balanced but there wasn't much choice, probably because it was closing. 
Staff was attentive and helpful and the environment was really nice. Overall, I would recommend it.
author: Erika J L.

description:
Kaitenzushi 回転寿司!

For some reason, Charlie Chaplin's classic "Modern Times" scene comes to mind

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DfGs2Y5WJ14&feature=kp

and let's not forget "eating machine"

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n_1apYo6-Ow

It is a pretty big deal when a food icon from Japantown disappeared...and that would be the fixture known as "Maki" which won the hearts of everyone except the FOBenese types. High end "bento" jewel box like square shaped arrangements...little portions for a pretty high price...and this was before the high tech hipsters with option$ rolled in. Maki wasn't that great to be honest...but compared to what we have now, some of us probably wished it never went away. I'm sure it is like Hong Kongers wishing the British would re-colonize Hong Kong again, and feel like a real ass democracy for once, instead of a makeshift puppet put in by Beijing. So much for high tea, cricket, rugby, milk tea, Britpop, soccer under a sea of redness.

The owner of Sushi Raw saw an obvious opportunity here for the space, and rightfully so...converted whatever small restaurant space into a conveyor belt operation. And business is brisk to say the least.

I would have to agree, Tenroku is a lot better than Isobune.
And compared to other Peninsula options for sushi boat/moat/conveyor belts, far superior.

Tenroku easily appeals to the Cantonese speaking expat Chinese community. Good portions, a large wide variety, and even a few classics are well represented here. But you also have The Weird, The Whack, and The Freaks on display.

Salmon - when all else fails, hard to go wrong with this. Hong Konger run of the mill types see this as the definitive fish for sushi, and somehow, salmon sashimi = Japanese cuisine in their eyes. So if you are running a serious sushi belt or boat business and you do not have salmon, may the Chinese lords have mercy on you.

Anago - Can I just pay homage to Sir Mixx A Lot, "I Like Big Cuts and I Cannot Lie".
For a sushi boat moat belt shop, the anago here is very decent. Of course please do not compare it with the greats in town who go through the painstaking process of preparing it and also pairing it with a molasses like consistency brush sauce/nikiri.

Saba - Nice big cuts. Not bad. At least safer than some of the dubious options

Crab - dry and not flavorful. Skip

Tempura jive ass roll - when you are hungry and other options are looking a little freaky and weird. Too bad it's room temp/cold

Lobster salad - unfortunately this was not good, surprisingly. Too mushy in texture.
Please skip this and you will thank me later.

Now the weird

I've seen a few entire trays of sea urchin on these black rectangular plates doing the rounds. The one during my visit looked pretty sad....maybe 1/3 of it looked a tad too oxidized.... nobody touched it. I first thought these were the $2 plates, but those are black and round. So who knows how much they cost. I guess even the HK FOB types know what's going on... 

There is some sort of crab or shrimp or lobster salad stuffed cucumber roll. But damn, it looks like some Cantonese prep of loofah/silky melon stuffed with shrimp paste and steamed....

Kimchi cucumber mini slices? Really?!

And many many other jive asssssss rolls.

If you navigate carefully in here, you will probably avoid the sha boo boo. :-o
author: Ken K.

description:
I've been here twice now and had a great dinner both times. Because of the seating style, the wait is definitely longer if you have a larger party and want to sit together.

I love the conveyer belt mechanism. The sushi on rotation is fresh because the chefs are constantly making more as plates are taken off. The only downside is that sometimes certain parties upstream from you may keep grabbing plates that you want. However, the chefs are very attentive and if you ask for a specific plate, they will usually have it made within a minute or two.

The sushi itself (I've only tried nigiri) is great and I can't really complain about it.
author: Jason W.

description: Their salmon belly nigiri is amazing and I get like 5 plates every time. It's a fun place to get a quick meal and peruse all of their fish selections as they go past. We come here all the time to celebrate small occasions.
author: Robin C.

description:
I'm not too fond of conveyer belt sushi, but this one was pretty decent. It's located in Japantown and never seem to have too much of a wait. Because it's conveyer belt sushi, food is served immediately! So it's a great option if you are dying of hunger at the moment. 

Service: 
The service here was nice and friendly. Not really attentive, but they are easy to flag down. 


Food: 
The food here is actually pretty good. Although, I wish they had more of a variety of sushi. Most of the options were pretty much one type of underlying sushi with a different topping or sauce on it. There were a couple of dishes that I particularly had a liking to - the one with the orange sauce on top. I don't know what it was, but would definitely recommend it. 

But I have to admit this place is very reasonable priced and the quality is great. 

Overall: 
I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Christina L.

description: Warning: fresh means raw and high quality. Fresh pinkish fish is hamachi. Fresh prawns and hotate, clean. I could eat here for two hours. Unless your date gets squirmish about fresh hotate, fresh prawns and avocado, you might be better off alone dining here. My BF has been to Japan, I haven't. Credibility versus opinion. Who wins!?! To each his own! Cheers!!!
author: farida r.

description: We were in Japan town and just ate delicious ramen from Suzu but saw a sign outside Tenroku that said $10 box of Santa Barbara uni. We walked in and realized it was a bar top, conveyer belt, self plating sushi restaurant. We asked for the uni box and were told they did not have any. Way to get our hopes up :/. We decided to try a couple plates anyways since you pay per plate. After staring at everything go past us on the conveyor belt with no interest, we decided to just grab anything to try.  I grabbed the seared blue fin toro which had fried onion flakes over rice. It was actually pretty fresh and melted in my mouth. We also grabbed the salmon eggs that did not taste too fresh. After trying two other items, I saw raw oysters! Threw some wasabi on there, took it whole, and was not pleased at all. There was sooooo much sand in there, I had to swish a lot of water to make sure I didn't chew it and ruin the enamel of my teeth! It also had a very very fishy after taste. Gross. We paid our bill and left. It was pretty pricey also. Each plate that we chose was about 5 dollars for two tiny pieces. The only reason why I am giving them more than one star is because the sushi chefs kept checking up on us to see how we were doing and if we needed anything else.  Definitely won't be coming back! We should have yelped it first but we're so intrigued by the uni sign.
author: an l.

description: The service here is great! I came with two young kids and they were extremely accommodating and even nicer than they needed to be. Thank you!
author: Ellie S.

description:
The understanding when entering a conveyor belt sushi restaurant is that you are sacrificing quality for cost. Unfortunately at this place the price is not much cheaper than a regular sushi restaurant and the quality is particularly low.

Each plate ranges from around $3 to $7. An average roll plate with 3 piece is $4.50. That means for a normal right piece roll you are paying over $10 for fish that has been sitting around and becoming less attractive with each rotation. The typical amount of sushi the average person eats will set you back about $30, which is just a few dollars less than it would cost to have fantastic freshly made sushi in San Francisco.

Aside from the price, everything was quite visually unappealing. The fish, even in the case, looked dried out. There were plastic covers on top of each dish which were beat up and foggy, definitely didn't make the dishes look appetizing. It also smelled a little funky in the restaurant.

This place might be decent if you are looking specifically for the conveyor belt sushi experience. Otherwise you can find much better sushi for a similar price elsewhere in the city.
author: Michael S.

description:
(2.5 stars) My friend urged me to give this place a try and after seeing some photos of their Blue Shrimp and $10 Uni box, heck why not? Haven't had conveyor belt sushi since high school. First of all don't have high expectations for kaiten-zushi in America, so don't expect Michelin star level sushi because that's not what you're gonna get. I see some of the negative reviews here and they're expecting fxxcking "Jiro I Dream of Sushi" grade sushi, are you stupid? Would you walk into McDonald's and write a bad review because they don't have Wagyu Beef burger?

This is a budget class Chinese owned (Sushi Raw owner) kaiten-zushi. The level after supermarket sushi. Get that into your heads people. Nijiya supermarket across the street has $9.99 Uni box, this place only charges $0.01 more, what the hell do you expect? Geez...

They had Walu crossed out on their menu which was disappointing. I had their sake toro topped with ikura, chutoro, saba sashimi, hamachi toro sashimi, kobe beef nigiri (yeah right!), amaebi nigiri, blue shrimp sashimi, ikura nigiri, uni nigiri. First of all, there is no Kobe Beef in the US, there is but in such small quantities the 99% cannot afford it. Seriously. If that was genuine Kobe Beef from Kobe, Hyōgo Prefecture those 2 pieces would cost you AT LEAST $50USD. Go read up on what is 100% genuine Kobe Beef, I'm not here to give you free lessons.

Honestly all the pieces I had were not bad, the rice was meh, but expected, still better than supermarket sushi rice. Here's a tip when eating at this place, order from the chef directly and order everything sashimi (no rice), at least your seaweed will be crisp and crunchy and not all soggy.

The reason I'm giving this place 2.5 stars is because both my friend and I had to glue ourselves to the toilet after we got home, if it was just me or my friend then maybe one of us is having stomach problems, but the both of us?

For the price this place is great, the portions are generous and if you're in a hurry for lunch you'll be in and out in no time. If it wasn't for the upset stomach afterwards I would've given this place 4 stars. Now I'm scared to go back.
author: Panchali S.

description:
A few words of advice: Manage your expectation. 

If you're here for quantity consumed with disregards for the quality of the fish you are provided then you are golden. Paying $4.5/a pair of nigiri will get you full but that's different from getting you the satisfaction that you've enjoyed a good quality fish or sushi rice that is properly prepared. It's not great but it can get you full. Nothing more. 

The postscript of my experience here is taking a peek at Isobune and realizing that the sushi on their boat is actually better looking.
author: Taffany H.

description:
Attempted the ramen festival on Sunday only to find myself laughing derisively as I stared at hundreds of people standing in line for an $8 bowl of ramen and realized I wasn't going to walk away with a single noodle. Since I was in Japantown, I asked my guy if we should just attempt to get some ramen from one of the restaurants in the Kintetsu Mall, to which he whole-heartedly agreed.

Our usual place is Katsu, but since it's closed for remodeling we decided to stop by Tenroku as we passed by, intrigued by the sushi conveyor. As we plucked our sushi from the belt when we saw things that looked appetizing, we perused the menu and decided on the ramen we wanted; however, apparently they were out of ramen (and something tells me it probably wasn't coincidental...), so we got udon noodles in our soups instead, which was still very good. Oddly, though we both ordered tonkotsu ramen we got chicken katsu instead, but the chicken was very good and the broth was very rich and flavorful. The portions were very generous as well, so much so that we couldn't finish our ramen after having the sushi as well.

All of the various rolls we enjoyed were fresh and extremely tasty, and it was cool sitting and watching the sushi chefs make the sushi in front of you and then plate it up to put on the conveyor. This is a fun place to come with friends or that special someone because of the atmosphere sitting at the sushi bar and having fun deciding which sushi you want and not always knowing what's in front of you. 

Great restaurant in Japantown, and very friendly staff as well. Prices are pretty reasonable here, too.
author: Angela M.

description:
We came here twice! They have a good selection, prompt service, and good prices.
It's really fun to watch the sushi parade and pick them up as we see them. I am really gonna miss this place.
author: Clau O.

description: Used to go to Isobune until a friend recommended. Super fresh nigiri and a lot of options. Will totally be going back. Only issue is we ate way too much :P
author: Tiffany F.

description:
I'm still burping up fish in my mouth. I just ordered two things in tonight's visit which were: tamago and the toro. Toro is hit or miss. Due to the massive after taste in my mouth I can only assume the quality of the fish was a miss tonight. Being 10 dollahs a plate shouldn't your fish be top notch? Head honcho? Big kahuna? Minus one star. 

The other subtracted star is because the chef tried to pull a switcheroo on me when I ordered two fresh orders of toro from him. HE TRIES AND TAKES THE TORO THAT HAS BEEN SITTING ON THE BELT AND GIVES IT BACK TO ME WITH ONE FRESH ORDER! I SEE YOU FOOL! YOU AINT NO NINJA! 

Not the best business practices here people. ://
author: Katie M.

description:
*edited* 

Let me make it clear since someone wrote me a comment asking why i am complaining over 1 order- unagi bowl. And why the hell did i even order that.  Anyways, that is ... of course not the only thing we've order, duh.  We only ordered that because everything else wasnt good... and we were still hungry. I dont write reviews to push a company down, it is my real experience and i dont care what others think.  Thank you

Im writing this as I'm eating.  I hate to give 1 star reviews but this place is overpriced for the quality they serve. Unagi bowl came out like a child serving size with old salad greens that are obviously not edible.  I am so mad at myself for being hungry and randomly stumbled upon this. Service is ok. Oh did i mention about the rice. .. it was horrible. Yea the rice was hard and was stuck to my teeth.
author: Anna W.

description:
This is the first conveyor belt sushi place I had ever been to. I was in total awe when I first sat down and I just wanted to grab everything that was conveying in front of me!

I grabbed a plate of the pickled cucumbers before my boyfriend could add his two cents and started eating them immediately. I thought they were delicious but my bf told me that most of the food on the belt was probably old and not fresh. Since we're dealing with raw fish, I decided to order off the menu to ensure total freshness. 

We had the Alaska roll, the spicy tuna roll, and the dragon roll cuz fb wanted shrimp tempura. All three were pretty good. Id say the Dragon was the best one, then Alaska and spicy tuna. Tenroku also serves free hot tea. 

I'm giving this place a 3 star rather than 4 because the food on the belt did not look the freshest. The edamame looked very dry and the raw fish in the conveyor rolls were not kept cold at all. The oysters weren't on ice. I'd be scared to eat any of it. 

Food wasn't bad but I probably wouldn't come here again.
author: Vidya K.

description:
I wouldn't come back to this place. 2 stars instead of 1 because the servers were nice.
Three other friends and I came in here for a birthday lunch and we weren't impressed. 
Seating is only around the conveyor belt. Everything was expensive- our bill came out to $90 and we weren't even full. I would say each of us had an average of 5 plates but every plate you reach for adds up quickly and unexpectedly in price. Each plate starts at $2.00 (for example, edamame) up to $10 (for example, a plate of uni). I wouldn't mind pricey sushi if the fish were fresh and delicious but they weren't.
Overall, nothing spectacular here and I would never crave this place. Definitely experienced better.
author: Grace L.

description:
Decent place but nothing to write home about. Conveyer belt sushi is the Japanese equivalent of McDonald's fast food. You can get seated fast. And your food is there waiting for you. The fish is reasonable fresh, decent cuts, and moderately priced. Great choice if you are looking for some quick decent sushi.

I would suggest going during peek times, otherwise your fish has done the conveyer belt grand prix for a while.
author: James S.

description: Excellent sushi bar. Intimate, crowded, happy chefs. Wonderful fish. Plus unusual things not normally on the menu like fried shrimp heads and salmon gills. Plus all the approachable sushi.
author: Frank C.

description:
Definitely better than Isobune, the rotating boat place downstairs.  Price is good and place is clean(er).  Sushi isn't the freshest, but best for the price.  Come here if you are seeking value!

We only ordered 3 dishes from the conveyor:

1. Salmon avocado maki: good, decent
2. some sweet escargot/snail sushi. My caucasian boyfriend was curious. and described it as "chewy". I had to eat the rest of it -_-
3. Uni. I love uni. the coloring seemed a bit off but tasted great and a 2 huge pieces for $6

We ordered:
- lobster tartare ($6. it wasn't entirely lobster - had roe and horseradish in it, but worth it)
- sea bass steak ($12) - huge filet of seabass. also worth the money but had bones in it
- chicken karaage ($6) - a bowl of fried chicken. delicious!
- otoro, hamachi, and waru sashimi.  The waru was especially worthy it given the $3.5 price tag.  The otoro was decent, especially for $6.

Our total bill came out to $55 for 2.  Not bad for sushi and not bad for a total paleo meal!
author: Alice Z.

description: Tenroku sushi is a great casual place for a light dinner or lunch. Be aware that it's a kaitenzushi where all the diners line up at a conveyor belt, this means it's a little noisy and lacks privacy but I think that chasing your favourite dish around the room is half the fun. You can order al a carte from the sushi chef and some hot dishes from the kitchen. The sushi is always consistent and there is a reasonable amount of traditional sushi, unlike many places in America. A handy casual eatery close to Kabuki cinema, nothing flash but good quality and I always leave satisfied.
author: Amaya B.

description:
Tenroku Sushi is conveyor belt delievered sushi. ambivalent about rating this tenroku.

small island of conveyer belt surrounded by a few tables.

eats: plates start at $2
-hamachi(4)
fresh
-sabe(3.5)
fresh, kind of fishy tasting/smelling
-albaocre(3.5)
supposedly got the belly section, fresh, very smooth.
sushi pretty good, rice kept falling apart.
good fish portions.

temaki:
-seating sucks, too tiny a space at turnaround- 2 stars
-good value but ambience is terrible, tight seating.
-nice peopled, all chinese though.
-wouldn't come again, just come for the value, not the ambience.
author: Victor G.

description:
tried this place for lunch..they are newly opened the service was not bad.they always check up on you and makes sure that you have everything you need.
I wasnt so happy about the selection of the sushi well maybe because Im not a fan of sashimi's but it was ok.The price is reasonable unlike the other sushi boat in japantown lol
author: Enah N.

description: The fish and the taste are only okay. It is an interesting experience of Kaitensushi so it's novel and fun. I prefer ordering from the menu - the hot prepared food is better. The volcano rolls, jalapeño rolls and the garlic edamame are all good. This place didn't work for me, but for many it's an okay lunch place. Service is good
author: Dilys S.

description: Fish weren't fresh at all but the raw shrimp. It felt pretty mediocre - I was there 5 years ago and it so much better and fresher.
author: Eliran M.

description: Awesome sushi in Japan town, for sure try the salmon special!! Probably the best sushi bar for the price around here. Chefs are friendly and take custom orders more than happily!
author: Robert R.

description: Great sushi bar in Japantown. Lots of dishes on the bar and also made to order. Reasonable prices. No matcha at your seats though, you need to ask for the tea. The place is nice but atmosphere could be better.
author: Clémentine C.

description: For my son's 16th Birthday we wandered thru JTown. We stopped for a quick snack for the first time. It was TOTALLY worth it. The staff is very enviting. The prices are VERY reasonable and the sushi is fantastic. There is limited seating, but it is fast food at a high quality and great value!
author: Orleana P.

description: Absolutely delicious food and they offer a wide variety of nigiri and sashimis. I would recommend this to anyone who loves sushi!
author: Steve L.

description:
Haven't have conveyor belt sushi for a long time in SF since Tomo was close (Isobune sucks), saw this new place last week decided to give it a try this weekend and was not disappointed.

Service is excellent and the sushi chef is super friendly, price is a bit high but hey as we all know Japantown is a tourist trap so it is acceptable :D . We had 9 different plates and a tempura our bill came close to $50, fish is pretty fresh, but some of the sushi stay on the belt for a long time, like the Scallop sushi had been circling the belt the entire time we're there, so pay attention on what you pick, and lack of many of my favor like Kane (crab leg), Toro (fatty tuna) and Hokkigai (giant clam) which are often available in other sushi place. 

No parking validation is a draw back, garage parking in Japantown is getting expensive lately :( but we did have a good time there, will likely to come back and hope they have more to offer in the future.
author: Faust T.

description: I love this newest addition to the SF kaiten (conveyer belt) sushi scene. In fact as all the other places are sushi boats, this is actually the first authentic kaiten in San Francisco. The quality is fresh, choices abundant, and they even cover the offerings with a clear plastic lid so the guy across the way the annoying cough won't adulter your future choice of food. The have great sake selection at a perfect price. And the crowds haven't quite discovered this place which is good- guess I'm sorta shooting myself in the foot here, but c'est la vie, I'd rather this place by busy than go out of biz.
author: Brian J.

description: Fresh, Fast and inexpensive . Chile Uni $7 for two(a steal), seared hirami , chu toro( $7 no brainier ), hamachi toro, unagi w/avocado/cucumber , spicy scallop hand roll , amaebi ($7 ;))))band a large hot saki for under $40 ...WHOA !!!!!!  Why pay double the price when you can fore fill your cravings for 1/2 the price . Another Uni Plssssss
author: Joe L.

description:
Kaiten sushi places are kinda like the bomb.com because you can pick what you want and its ready to go right away making a meal super fast. People hate on it because its not fresh but with the number of people eating, I think its ok. I usually go to Sakana Bune because its cheaper and has pretty good variety but we were in the area so we went here. They are indeed one of the better Kaiten sushi places and they also ahve a menu that you can order from. Pricing is higher by quite a bit but the cuts are significantly bigger than Sakana Bune. I think they have more variety too and a lot of more exotic stuff. The plates are also covered as well for those that are germaphobic. 

The restaurant overall is kinda small and its pretty cramped. There isn't much walk space between the walls and the seats. I like it but just wish price was lower! Will def be back.
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
I'm a sashimi person and this is one of my go-to places for expensive cuts like Otoro. Most other places I had in downtown area before has great quality fish. But at over $10 fog two piece of Otoro is just little too much of a rip-off. Tenroku, though it is not super high-end quality Otoro every time, still beats the other places in terms of prices ($6!!!) and phatttt ass cut. On top of that, they still do a good job with the average stuff like anago sushi and spider-roll. And most if the time, their hamachi sashimi are fresh, thick, and cheap. 

That's why I'm here all the time, and the 大将in the front middle is my amigo now lol. Dude is bro.
author: William W.

description:
Tenroku is clean, and I appreciate that they put plastic lids on everything. Makes for a slightly cramped eating space, but at least I know no one has laughed on my food! I've only been to conveyor belt sushi places a few times prior, and this is one of the best I went to. Fish was fresh enough, as there were plenty of people seated. A good variety, as well.

The cheapest and most expensive plates are black, with expensive plates featuring a pattern. I grabbed a black plate and only noticed the flower pattern after I lifted the sushi up... I'm sure there's another color that could be used for one or the other.

As others have mentioned, the place is a little small and cramped. There was also this family that kept staring at my boyfriend and I... in such a small place, it was definitely more than a little uncomfortable. I won't knock the place for it, though. It's not their problem!

We arrived in a rush, ate, and paid within 15 minutes. Service was quick and friendly. Will definitely be back next time I'm in the area.
author: Michelle E.

description: Ok first off don't get my high review rating confused...this is a sushi boat style restaurant so for that being said, we really liked this place. They have a lot of different items to choose from and they can still make to order just about anything you like as well. For a sushi boat style joint the freshness was pretty good and the amount of different types of sushi available was excellent as well. They have your standards, salmon, tuna, Cali rolls etc but they also have uni, toro and I didn't really see anything fried either which is a plus. The wait staff weren't really on top of pouring tea but if you got their attention they would be right on it. Prices are very reasonable for a sushi place and well if you're like us by the time you're done we have stacks of plates to be tallied, it was almost embarrassing...almost.
author: Guisela L.

description:
Previous review below (so you can see how bad it's gotten). This place used to be great, but they just received a low health score and I can vouch for it. I watched them pass dirty dishes ABOVE the sushi and food/water dripped onto the passing food. I alerted them immediately and they DID NOT REMOVE THE CONTAMINATED FOOD FROM THE BELT.

------------------

This is the best conveyor belt sushi I've ever had. Granted, I've only been to one of those kinds of places three times but this one was so much better than the other two, I really feel it merits five stars. 

The belt was filled with different types of sushi and they all looked fresh and well made. The staff is also ultra friendly and attentive. My tea never got cold or ever dropped below half full. Also, the seats are farther apart from each other then the other places I've been. I didn't feel crammed in like a sardine while I was there. Though I think if you were an especially tall or wide person you might still have some issues during the ultra-busy times. 

I had several orders of a shrimp tempura style role, a salmon roll with lemon and unagi (eel) here. All were amazing. The tempura one was fried but light, the salmon one tasted ultra fresh and almost had a palate cleansing effect, and the eel was perfect with no flabby or slimy parts to it. 

If I had had more time in SF I would have gone here many more times. It was really great, and MUCH cheaper then the other converyer belt sushi places I've been to.
author: Cori N.

description:
I was very disappointed by the quality of the tobiko (flying fish eggs) and ikura (salmon eggs). Both were very flavorless and borderline inedible. 

The salmon sashimi was good, and the rolls were fine. Everything else was pretty mediocre.
author: Ryan H.

description:
We were in the area, so we figured sushi in Japantown would be a great idea. I don't know why I thought this; the ramen I'd had downstairs a few weeks ago was vile. What made me think the sushi nearby would be better?

I don't know. It was the contact high I got coming out of Kinokuniya. That bookstore always makes me so damned happy, and I'm gonna blame it.

Tenroku has minimal table seating and predominately caters to sushi-boat lovers. We sat down and ordered an Asahi for two and received some hot green tea to boot. I think I sat there and watched the belt loop around two or three times before slumping in my chair with the questionable "rainbow"-looking roll. With three pieces (priced at $4), I ate the California roll draped with a meager piece of salmon. I could've done without the mayo explosion (in the California roll), so I asked the sushi chef for a simple sake nigiri (salmon on rice). That was just fine. None of the silky creaminess that salmon usually has.

Look, I know I'm being incredibly nit-picky here, but once you get used to excellent sushi (which San Francisco totally has), everything else is just... sigh, not as great. Service was just fine, but because of the lack of food quality, I don't see myself revisiting Tenroku anytime soon.
author: Adena B.

description:
This place is your normal type of "sushi boat" restaurant.  I really enjoy two things here: crab salad nigiri and the takoyaki.

The wait staff is ok, but I really like the Hispanic sushi chefs.  They're really nice and will make you anything on the fly.  Not a place I would die for to come, but it's adequate.
author: Eddie F.

description:
Solidly mediocre. Servers were nice. Tamago was middle of the road, likely bought from elsewhere. 

Fish didn't look so good, likely below average. Not terrible, but not worth eating. Especially since prices are comparable to Kabuto (my heaven). Yeah. 

I wanted to like this place since the other kaitenzushi in Japantown is always packed. Now I know why. 

Sorry, I have to speak honestly. They are trying but the standards are too low. I recommend they hire a sushi consultant. Kaiten doesn't have to equate with mediocre, and they need some expert guidance to make some changes. I think they can get there, if they have the desire.
author: Paul K.

description: Miguel such a great guy who help us, made my experience so great. I salute you Miguel.
author: Machetero B.

description: Well, this is just clearly, a 2-star establishment. Simple sushi in the style that goes around in a circle and you grab it off the plate. Nothing special at all. Not a place for a good date, but perhaps a place for a quick bite before the movies at Kabuki. Some of the sushi was a bit luke warm when it should have been hot. The wait staff were attentive enough to get a beer but did not help for much else. Definitely not terrible, but not good either.
author: Brian S.

description: First time came to this sushi boat restaurant! Prices are reasonable. Surprised there were not that many people today! We've been seated right away! Food is on average. Great environment! Minus two stars for service because my friend asked 3 times for hot water! My brother and my tea cup was empty for a long while, waitress did not pay any attention until we asked twice! There were not that many customers, therefore, I couldn't find her an excuse for it!!
author: Katherine L.

description:
This is not the kind of sushi joint that you come after seeing Jiro Dreams of Sushi.  You don't sit timidly in front of the sushi chef hand select grains of rice one at a time, waiting for his mastery to unfold.  Tenroku has a sushi converyor belt: that should be the focus of your dining experience. 

It's the perfect place to take your never-seen-sushi-run-in-a-circle child.  Besides the obvious draw of the moving feast, the food selection suits the little one as well.  He is not here to test the freshness of uni, elasticity of tuna.  I gave him a plate of octopus with tentacles sticking out and he is as happy as can be.  

For the parent, the choices are good too.  My hotate nigiri and salmon nigiri were both good.  And a plate of edamame for $2 kept me busy while watching my son "savor" the Ramune soda, sip by sip. 

Prices are really reasonable, so it's not like you are shelling out $200 for a meal where your son tells you the best part was the marble that can't come out of the soda bottle.  It was a little over $40 for us, which I am totally happy with. 

The place fills up around 12:30, but that's also when sushi choices become a little more varied and exciting.  So your optimal arriving time is within a window of about 10 minutes.
author: Candice B.

description:
This place is consistent. The revolving sushi belt style means turnover is quick. I've never needed to wait too long for a seat. 

The food is good but not amazing. If you're looking for fair-priced sushi this is def the place to try.
author: Calvin L.

description:
After watching Jiro Dreams of Sushi and reading some sushi articles, I decided to eat sushi the traditional way (none of those deep-fried fish combinations drenched in unnatural sauce). 
The chef behind the counter was attentive and friendly. I stuck with the healthy basics: seafood and rice. My favorites were the fatty tuna Toro and Ama-ebi sweet shrimp. The blue fin tuna, salmon, and hamachi sashimi slices were thick and delicious. Oh yeah, can't forget the underrated Saba (mackerel) and Herring Roe. Chased it all down with hot sake and ended with tomago.
author: James L.

description:
A new place in the J Town mall, on the west end, second floor, across from the book store. Friendly welcome, not crowded and pretty small. Sushi plates on metal conveyor belt, great variety, all very fresh. Oysters perfect, Cali roll yummy, and such clever rolls on offer. Add a nice beer or sake and dig in. Very helpful staff, friendly chefs. Yay! 
Enjoy!
author: William M.

description: Definitely one of my favorite places to eat in Japan Town. I just keep on going back to it every time I'm in Japan town. It's an awesome place.
author: Francis D.

description: By far our fav low key regular sushi. Consistent, delicious, friendly. Plus the $10 uni tray deal. Cheap fast fun dinner. Always come out happy. Don't change anything
author: j j.

description: This place is awesome. Usually pretty crowded and is also a bit pricier than the neighboring restaurants within the mall. Great toro and hamachi - which are actually pretty reasonably priced considering the quality.
author: Leo C.

description: Probably one of my favorite places, well priced fresh sushi, great quality for a sushi belt place. Be careful how much you get, it easily adds up to $100+ but still worth it.
author: Jessica S.

description:
I have to laugh reading other reviews. If you have tried enough Sushi restaurants, you will have a better sense of giving "stars".  I'm writing this review sitting inside the restaurant now.  I'm with my husband and my 10yr old daughter.  And it's 4:30pm on a Sunday afternoon. 

Food & Price:
- Quality of food match their price. There's no free lunch or cheap lunch. You pay for what you get. Most plates are within the $3-$5 range.  You just can't compare to a place serves $5/piece of sushi.  
- Freshness OK to GOOD, at least each plate has a cover to avoid drying and fish doesn't smell
- Portions GOOD, they don't give you a huge rice ball with tiny fish slice. Both are reasonable size 
- varieties GOOD, 

Service:
Nothing bad and just average.  The setting is not a sit down restaurant but sushi bar. They come around and serve tea, towel, clean up, appropriate service for this type of place. Sushi chefs are friendly and waitresses are ok too.

Overall, it's a good place with ok food and ok price.  Will come back next time we are in SF if we want a quick nite.
author: P T.

description: I love this place as an alternative to An sushi and Sushi Sam. They're fish are all fresh and delicious. Came here twice and Uni didn't look too good though.  I go there for their raw shrimp, salmon belly, blue fin toro, scallop! All fresh and tasty and decent prices!! I think an order of salmon belly nigiri was no more than $10, probably around $7 or $8 for 2 pieces. At An or Sushi Sam, it can range from $10-$20 for 2 pieces!
author: Alyce l.

description:
THIS PLACE ONLY DESERVES "MINUS" STAR, NOT EVEN "0"!  IF YOU COME HERE WITH A BABY OR KIDS, BY ALL MEANS AVOID THIS PLACE!  

WE GOT KICKED OUT IN THE MIDDLE OF A MEAL, JUST BECAUSE WE HAD A BABY AND A STROLLER BY THIS OLD, UGLY, RUDE WOMAN WHO MAYBE A MANAGER!

DO NOT COME HERE AT ALL!  SHE WON'T TREAT YOU WELL, AND WILLING TO KICK YOU OUT, AND QUESTION WHY YOU WANT TO TAKE THE LEFTOVER HOME AFTER YOU DECIDE TO LEAVE! 

My husband and I arrived with our baby in the stroller, and got seated in the back by the usher/waitress.  I had been here before WITH THE BABY AND THE STROLLER and decided to come back with my husband.  In the middle of our meal, and we have ordered a lot, I needed to take our baby to change.  So I went out with the stroller with the baby in it.  Other customers did not mind at all as I walked out with the stroller, where they had to make space so I could get through.

Then when I went back, this OLD UGLY RUDE woman out of nowhere stopped me and told me that I have to leave the stroller outside because I would disrupt her customers, and she was being rude about it.  HELLO OLD DEPRESSED UGLY lady, WE ARE YOUR CUSTOMER TOO, AND IN THE MIDDLE OF EATING!  I told her where we were seating, and pointed where my husband was.  Then, I saw a table outside, so I told her we should move there and switch place, but then she said people are seating there.  I saw this couple, they just arrived and were about to be seated, they were not seating down!   What a bullshit!   Basically she kicked us out!

When we told her we were seated where we were seating, she told us the waitress was new.  BUT, this OLD UGLY RUDE woman only said "sorry" and didn't do anything else!  When we said we were leaving, she gladly and quickly gave us a check.  No comp, no effort to make us stay!  WHAT A BAD PERSON!  Then, when I told her to pack the leftover uni, she had the nerve to say "you want this, only 2 left".  WHAT A BIG B!  Of course we wanted to take all of the leftovers!  

After we walked out, I went back in and really complained again, and told her how upsetting the whole situation was!  Again, only empty sorry, and no other things done!  

I really wish SHE GOT TRAINED how to be a manager of a restaurant.  It is a hospitality industry, but she is way beyond hospitable!  SHE NEEDS TO BE SCHOOLED!  

If your waitress made a mistake, then as a manager you should be able to rectify the situation, not make it worse!   It is a simple sitting arrangement for God's sake! 

If this OLD UGLY RUDE PERSON IS ANTI BABIES, KIDS, STROLLERS, PLEASE ANNOUNCE THAT IN FRONT OF YOUR RESTAURANT!  SAVE US TIME, ENERGY, AND AGGRAVATION!

We did leave a tip tho we didn't have to, for the sushi chef (Miguel) and the waitresses.   I hope they will get the tip not this rude person.

You know, what goes around comes around!  YOU WILL GET YOUR KARMA!
author: Meiko S.

description: How could this place not get a 5 star rating?! It's a sushi boat style sushi restaurant but the sushi is all really fresh and literally within arms reach! Price depends on the color of the plate. You can also order off the menu for a roll you want but mostly everything (sushi and nigiri, sashimi) is on the conveyer belt
author: Amber J.

description:
Fun, casual dining experience.  Delicious sushi, fun selection of unique rolls, great customer service.   

Fish was fresh and I love that it was easy to order directly from the sushi chef if I didn't see what I was after on the carousel.
author: Kate R.

description: This sushi place is awesome. It's our new favorite hide away. The sushi is always fresh and unique. Not stale and the same thing plate after plate like Isobune. Love the variety of choices. We love this place. Hope it can stay our little secret for awhile longer.
author: Keith R.

description: we were on a wait-list next door but gave up and decided randomly go into this one. we had a good time and food. it was nice to watch the chefs making all kinds of dishes right in front of us, which also made us want more - be aware! it's addictive. the chefs were polite and nice!
author: Duke B.

description:
Eh it's okay... nothing special.

Kaiten sushi in Japantown is unfortunately just so-so, so you just take what you get. Tenroku is pretty tiny but we didn't have to wait for a seat which was great =) After we sat down the servers brought us warm towels for our hands and hot tea which was legit. Didn't even have to ask! After that we dove in and grabbed a few of our favorites: tuna, salmon, crunchy roll... The sushi going around wasn't too bad, but keep an eye out because some of them looked like they had been going around for quite a long time.

We also ordered the soft shelled crab which was a great choice. It was a big serving and it tasted delicious! My boyfriend and I definitely enjoyed that in addition to our sushi. In the end our bill was about $40 for mediocre sushi which seemed like a lot, so beware of how many plates you are taking!
author: Sam F.

description: I didn't think they were very fresh fishes except for sea uruchi than I had experience like this in Japan
author: Goo F.

description:
I love the sushi boat concept. Random small plates that you just grab as it comes by. Make sure you grab it when you see it because it may not come around again... 

This is one of at least two sushi boats in the Japantown mall. I hadn't been to this one before and since this weekend was all about new experiences, it was a must.

All the plates have a clear dome covering it. I like that. We came in when it was still busy. Earlier it was more busy so we came back at a good time. Still people were in and out as long as we were there, so everything was very fresh. The uni was there the entire time... not everyone's fav apparently :)

The prices aren't bad. $1.00 - $10.00 plates. Average seemed to be ~$5 give or take. Depends on what you want and like. There were nice big chunks of sashimi and the rolls were usually 3 pieces.
I don't like asking for specific rolls and this place certainly didn't disappoint by having a good variety. Depending on where you sit, you can watch the chefs make the rolls and then request some of that because it looks so good. They pass it to you with a smile.

Sushi and large beers makes us happy and full.

I'll definitely come back here.
author: Sandra R.

description:
Went there today with my wife and had a horrible experience.   

Food: F

most of the food on the rotating conveyor is old and hasn't been changed out for a while.  A few plates came off after about 15 minutes, but we're talking 4 - 5 plates.  So you're just stuck sitting there watching the same food.  To make matters worse, the waitress snuck up on me and took my menu without asking, so I had to ask for it back so that I could actually order something I wanted.

Service: D-

They only get a D because the sushi chef Migel is a really nice guy.  The rest of the staff are completely untrained in customer service.  The "waitresses" continuously circle the area behind you, over and over and over like pesky flies.  I mean thanks for taking the plastic off my plate, but I think letting it sit there for more than 30 seconds is OK.  The owner was also very gruff and rude to us as well (you'll see the other post left by my wife).  You can see that her stiff and unaccommodating attitude really trickles down to her staff.  It's pretty pathetic.

Experience:  F

With so many other great options in Japantown, why would anyone come here?

It's like playing Russian roulette with old fish.  Who will be the sucker that is so hungry from waiting for a decent dish that he picks up the old stinky fish aging under the lights.
