It's undeniable... stick your head in the door.  It SMELLS!  Fresh fish doesn't smell, OK?  So there's clearly something wrong.

Tight quarters (barely space to squeeze behind customers), creepy service, crummy food and terrible management.  

JUST DO YOURSELF A FAVOR AND LISTEN TO YOUR NOSE.  THIS PLACE DOESN'T PASS THE SMELL TEST!
author: Scott B.

description: Friendly service and good food! You cant go wrong with the roles or sushi.  I particularly like the roles with jalapeños on em. Not sure of its name but it comes on a yellow plate. Whenever I'm craving sushi this is my go to spot! Then i usually head over to Kabuki! :)
author: Julia H.

description: THIS PLACE WAS BAD! This was the worst sushi place. The rice was so bad and the fish was not fresh at all. Ive never wrote a review on yelp. But this place was so bad. Dont come
author: Vivian K.

description:
I know conveyor/sushi boat is consisted quite gauche in some sushi loving circles but the 10 year old in me and the French Spouse loves the idea of endless options served immediately. Sadly what usually happens is you have low quality food or really basic rolls that are bland in taste. 

Tenroku's sushi and maki are a step up in quality and taste than most kaiten places including Isobune just down the hall. Normally I would never get amiebi or uni at place like this but both were freshly made and of a good quality.

The space is smaller than most US kaiten places and they cover the plates which I like but some people might find annoying. Since it is a small place there probably wasn't as many dishes out but we never lacked in choices and the server was quick to take our order for anything that was out. The space is very clean and modern, there is one booth but the counter is bar height and not wheelchair accessible.

The prices range from 2-6 for most dishes which is actually lower than other places especially for the quality of the fish.

This is a place to taking the visiting mid-west relatives or get a quick bit before a movie at the Sundance theater.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
I've been here a few times for sushi. They serve sushi via a conveyor belt and you simply grab the sushi you want and pay based on how many dishes you eat (each dish is priced according to its color). Overall, if you're looking for quick, decent sushi at a fair price, this is a great place.

My favorite ones are:
- Fatty tuna sashimi
- Salmon sashimi
- Eel nigiri 

There are loads more selection (a good strategy is to grab whatever looks tasty). I definitely recommend this place!
author: Lillian C.

description: Beware:  I work in Japantown and I've seen an employee of this restaurant (older female, short hair) leave the bathroom without washing her hands.  I've seen this multiple times.  Sometimes she will splash them with water to look like she's doing something, but I've never seen her use soap or dry her hands.  Super gross, I would avoid at all costs.
author: Denise M.

description: Located in the J-town mall near the bookstore.  We have been here a few times and the sushi and service have always been good.   We had many different types of sushi including the Toro which was excellent.  The only thing I would like to see is that they make more tekka and plain spicy tuna rolls.
author: Ken K.

description:
Solid conveyor belt sushi. I was surprised by the quality of the fishes that are offered here. The fried chicken (appetizer), scallop, toro, salmon, yellowtail and uni were all good. The only down side is that some of them were too cold when they're first put out on the conveyor belt... We had to wait for them to thaw a little

Prices ranged anywhere from $.99 to $10. Good hidden little gem in Japantown!
author: Maria H.

description: For a kaiten, it's alright, maybe even good. But if you want real, good sushi, this is not the place.
author: Lucas C.

description:
My rating weighs taste of food most heavily, and I'm surprised the place got only 3.5 stars on average from others.  The sushi is really great:  the rice is shaped and 'gripped' lightly, and crumbles pleasantly without resistance in your mouth, but no problem picking it up with chopstick -- that's a work of pretty well trained sushi chefs.  And the salmon (excellent), uni (a bit on the salty side, but great tasting without the soy sauce), the bluefin tuna (it really doesn't compare with the other types of tuna, no wonder it's overfished!), the flavored octopus, and everything else was excellent!  (I wish I tried the fresh octopus which was on the menu, rather than the boiled octopus, that's my one regret).

 I don't drink much alcohol, and this visit was no different, but maybe that made the great taste at Tenroku Sushi stand out more.  Went on a Thursday early lunch (before noon), so there was no line at all, and everything was coming out very fresh.  Highly recommended - I'm trying to see if I have the courage to seek out any other sushi places in San Fran.
author: K A.

description: We made a reservation for 7 people and showed up on time, however, they did not save seats for us. What's the point of accepting a reservation if you don't "reserve" the seats!?  Worse of all, they were non-apologetic about it and played dumb to the whole thing. What can I say? Typical Chinese restaurant behavior, i.e, crappy communication with customers.
author: Mitchell K.

description:
I feel bad for the owners of this restaurant but the concept was flawed from the start.

To do kaiten sushi right, you need volume and quick turnover. If you have the same crap going round and round getting stale this doesn't work. 

The current model at Tenroku to do high priced, low volume sushi is the opposite of what kaiten was designed for. It's like trying to do Costco out of a 10x10 foot strip mall with high prices.

Predictably, the sushi tasted bad. No offense, but the owners need to rethink this model.

I'm sorry but all of the 4-5 star reviews of this place are sketchy. Also, the fact that some of the reviews come from elite yelpers makes me think the quality of Yelp reviews is getting pretty poor and really just about volume.

Very sad that I couldn't trust Yelp to steer me to a decent sushi place.
author: Joseph K.

description:
Gah! 

I saw all the four star reviews and thought, GREAT, fresh, well-made sushi.  Perfect quick nosh on a movie night with my Mr.

What I got was slightly clammy, untasty fish.  They seem to want to sell you fancy, over-amplified superrolls with cute names.  The table full of 20-somethings next to us had things on fire, things that smoked, and things with so many different kinds of stuff draped over them that they looked like some kind of science experiment gone bad.

Me, I just wanted some *real* sushi.  Some yellowtail, maybe a barbecued eel roll, some tekka maki, a kappa maki, sake nigiri.

All of the above were available (except the BBQ eel roll) but every one of them was overpriced and mediocre.  Clammy, not so fresh fish.  Tough nori on the rolls.  Doesn't anybody toast nori anymore?

The service was abrupt and dismissive and unfriendly.  

IE.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Place was a little hard to find due to signage and numbers of suites not in numerical order. Decor was nice. Seating only around conveyor belt with rotating plates of sushi and other treats. Not ideal for groups of 4 or more as conversation would be tough. 

Sushi was very fresh. We also split a huge bowl of chicken ramen which was delicious. Broth was great and noodles fresh.  
 
Plates on conveyor belt range in price from $2-$6. Most come with 2-3 pieces of sushi. 

Staff was very helpful and friendly. Sushi chefs were also nice, answered all our questions on what the different dishes were. 

Plates quickly stack up so be careful!

Would def return
author: Davis C.

description:
I went to this place several times, and they didn't disappoint me once.
I love all the food they serve, and the salmon sushi and toro sushi are so good, fish is fresh, rice is well-cooked, I like this restaurant!! Really!!
author: Carrie L.

description: My husband and I were craving sushi one night and we walked into this little spot. This has become one of our favorite places to come for sushi. We typically get the sashimi plates and the nigiri plates that have been lightly torched. Really fresh tasting and it hits the spot. We're even coming back for my husband's birthday, and bringing the crew along =)
author: rissa m.

description: My first revolving sushi bar experience!  I eat sushi all the time, but, I've never enjoyed a sushi eating experience as much as I did at this place.  They have traditional and funky options and they were reasonably priced.  I had about 10 sushi plates for like $44.  I probably would have paid so much more at a traditional sushi restaraunt, and I wouldn't get the cool experience like I did here.
author: Wouldn't You L.

description:
Not a huge fan of conveyor belt sushi places. It didn't seem like they had a way to tell when the sushi was put into the belt, which means a piece of sushi could have been there for a couple of hours. 

With that said I ordered two rolls off the menu. It wasn't bad at all, and we got to see them make it right in front of us, though they were pulling out tupperware with fish in it, again not sure how fresh this is.
author: Krish P.

description: So, the strife in Japantown is a lack of amazing sushi.  It's something you're gonna have to deal with.  Tenroku is actually some of the better sushi to be found.  It's the conveyor belt sort of thing, so spend the time to look at the belt and what's coming out fresh.  The sushi was quite nice and the service was fast as expected.  But ya, unless its a sushi emergency, go elsewhere in the city...if you're in Jtown looking for a quick bite, this place serves well.
author: David S.

description:
My 1st review has been removed.
Cherylynn N. San Francisco, CA
Send me a Message says, "No wonder it sucks! It's owned by Sushi Raw people!"
So, that means, 100% Chinese.

Yes, this is US, anything goes. Who cares? No one does. You don't have to know the real sushi to open sushi restaurant. America is second China. Who cares? But just in case, if you have an experience having a real sushi, I am very sure you won't come here.

I am not impressed for this new Kai-ten Sushi restaurant.  Compared to the other popular conveyor/boat sushi place in Japantown (Isobune) this is not that much upgrade.  It means both bad.
Kobe Beef Nigiri? There is NO Real Kobe beef in US for your info. The specialty sushi on the menu are just a joke, yes, they are. I am very sure that they don't have well trained real sushi chef.
Just remember the sushi menu is all jiveassroll only so, .....

Pro tip:  Not worth to wait.  Like many sushi boat/conveyor belt places it gets busy during peak meal times for people who doesn't really know what the real Sushi is.
Oh God help us.
I knew it, Disappointed very much.
author: Nobu K.

description: Perhaps bad timing and definitely wrong expectation from us. When we visited, there were satisfied customers all over. For example, who keep picking and eating up sushi dishes from the rotating system. Yet all we see on the belt were pretty similar roll items with orange color sauces. We tried a few of them, and we felt that they were not quite unified. Then we tried toro nigiri that fish felt little too warm. And then we tried shelled oysters, which made us leave. We weren't sure what made other people happy. We'd go to a sushi place with no sushi boat next time.
author: Chacha M.

description: If you're looking for conveyor belt sushi, Tenroku will do the job. Overall, it's nothing spectacular, but the salmon sashimi and sweet shrimp nigiri are very very tasty!
author: Calvin W.

description: My favorite sushi place of all time! This sushi bar is everything you want a sushi bar too be! Delicious, fresh, variety, and good oysters!  I've tried many sushi bars before finding this one and they were all disappointing. You really just have to try it for your self to see what I'm talking about. So if you're in the sf Bay Area looking for a great sushi spot, check this out its a Amazing! And don't forget to try some oysters if you're a oyster type of person , they are bomb!
author: Flor P.

description: The place rocks overall. One time I got a really weird uni but after that are all good
author: Grizabella L.

description: I kinda really liked it - a conveyor belt sushi place. Wow. Toro was a steal at $6 (usually this would go for ~$15). Many of the rolls were tasty. Service was solid. I'd go back anytime.
author: Andrew K.

description: Love this place. Extremely friendly chef and staff. I went in the evening after rush hour so the chef paid special attention to my needs. Highly recommend the kobe beef nigiri.
author: Vivien S.

description: Right near Sophie's Crepes. Place is clean and seafood is fresh. They also do have toro, uni, scallops, ebi, etc. Not just your basic stuff. They also do some seared fish. The butter fish was amazing and just melts in my mouth. You can order some hot items too. The cod was so yummy and their tofu was good. I like that it was bite size pieces. For a quick and casual sushi meal, this hits the spot. Price can add up though.Will def come back.
author: Karen H.

description:
Sure, I've learned that this place is run by Chinese, but so what? This is San Francisco, after all, not Japan. The few bad reviews don't serve justice, so I'm here to give them an honest, good review. 

As a starter, I like it.

IMO, Tenroku is pleasant, clean and really offers a lot compared to their older rival, Isobune. Perhaps they are still new, but their service is great and staff is super friendly. The active sushi guys pay attention to you and make sure you have what you need. They have a good deal of o-toro nigiri for $6. Tastes succulent. 

Sure, people complain that their prices are a little high, but which restaurant in Japan Town aren't? If you need cheap food, go to Nijiya for a slab of fresh fish and make your own sushi at home. That will save some bucks.
author: Rika P.

description: I've eaten here multiple times but today wasn't a good day. I ordered a spicy tuna roll and the rice was very hard. Also all waitresses that were working at the time weren't doing a very good job. Took way too long to get a cup of ice water and for them to refill it. Today's experience wasn't a good one.
author: S M.

description:
Ok I guess. But not coming back. 
There are plenty of sources for sushi in SF that are much better. 
The waitress' level made me take one star.
author: Geordie E.

description: Terrible food, terrible service.  Wait staff are robotic, stiff and unfriendly.  Management is very rude as well.   The place smells like old fish too...  no thanks.  Not stroller friendly.
author: Scott B.

description:
Tenroku is a spanking new conveyor belt sushi joint in Japan town. More specifically, it is inside the Japan Center building close to the bridge, next to Festa Karaoke and Bar.

The place is pretty tiny. There is a bar where the  main conveyor part is and a few tables (3~4) that seat bigger groups. The prices are moderately fair, ranging from $3 to $6. Just to give you an idea, Ikura sushi, Salmon sushi, and Tuna sushi were all on the $4.50 plate, which is really not bad. For a small person like me, it only took 4 plates to fill up which came out to be around $20. I'm sure a bigger man could spend at least $30.

The freshness of the fish was pretty good. Out of the things I had, I thought the salmon was pretty good. The rolls I tried were just soso, although I thought a roll wrapped with cucumber was pretty good. 

I especially like conveyor belt sushi because you get to eat right away and you get to pick and choose what you want. All in all, I think this is a good addition to the plaza.

One thing - I think the rice in their sushi is packed too tight, making it kind of hard to eat. I don't want a mouthful of hard to break down rice, needing a glass of water to help it down.
author: Julie K.

description:
This is kaiten sushi meaning you pick out what sushi you want from a conveyor belt.

Perfect for fast eaters. You can be in and out in under 15 min.

Sushi quality is so so. 
Salmon - not fresh
Scallop - decent
Mackerel - decent
Rolls - good
author: Mark D.

description:
food was tasty.  service was acceptable but what I really disliked was a bento box is around $10, and basically comes with a protein, rice, salad and a miso soup.  Nothing else.  Oh but if you want to, you can add things for $3 or $5 each!   WTF?  no thanks...I feel like this is the spirit airlines of restaurants.  

The food didn't warrant the price.  I had the salmon bento with chicken Karaage, for $13.  Tiny portions and I left still hungry.
author: Matt V.

description: ahaha...I have to be careful with these sushi places!  They all look so good and the prices are pretty reasonable.  It was hard to get refills on drinks and there could be more variety to the sushi, but overall I really liked what I had, sushi was fresh, and thought the prices were good.
author: Be K.

description:
Mumsy and I came here in search of sushi on a Sunday lunch-hour. I know, I know, not the best time to go. Yelp to the rescue, so we chose this place as it has four stars. We both faltered when we saw the sushi boats (eek! sushi snobs do not like the boat thing) but thought screw it, we'll try it.

We were nicely surprised. We had a stack of plates - edamame, hamachi, which was fresh and buttery, the salmon, which was also fresh and butter, tender octopus, mackerel, and they made oshinko-maki roll just for Mumsy. The only thing she passed on was the ama-ebi which she eyed suspiciously. 

Service was excellent and friendly, and the price was good - I would definitely come back if I needed a sushi fix on a Sunday. I'll give it a 3 and a half stars for the first time. :)
author: Mi M.

description:
Tenroku Sushi is a new addition to the Japantown Center Mall in San Francisco. As you can see from the pictures, it's a conveyor style sushi joint. Some my be put off by this style of sushi restaurant but I decided it was worth a try and here are the main points I came away with:

1. Value was solid, the sushi quality was average to above average for a non-fancy sushi restaurant.
2. The staff was very attentive and nice. The restaurant itself was well lit and clean.
3. Service was quick, as expected with this type of sushi restaurant.

One thing I didn't like was the temperature of some of the sushi. You definitely don't want warm sushi (unless it's something cooked) but a few pieces of sushi served were too cold, almost as if it was pulled straight from a fridge that was set on max.

Last note: One the night I went, Tenroku was running a special on Blue Fin Toro sushi for $6.00 for two pieces. The quality of the Toro was surprisingly good for the price and well worth a try.
author: Denny C.

description:
Was our second choice after we all rushed to Sushi Zone to get in line and saw a posted paper towel in Sushi Zone window that said, 'Sorry Closed Today"!!!

I went with two Japanese food aficianados who have lived in Japan and are sushi snobs! Me, if it doesn't smell, I don't get sick from it, tastes fresh, salmon sashimi is salmon sashimi is unagi etc.

It's in Japantown, a fairly small place. It's bar seating with chefs in the middle and everything is in cafeteria bowls which threw me for cheap. The food was good, no complaints. Everything was fresh and it's the day after and I didn't get sick ;-) The prices were above average. I paid a bit more than I expected but no problem because of great staff

The fourth star is for service. The hostess and waitress passed by repeatedly offering tea and water. Both were also friendly, smiled, one even joked with me! The chef offered suggestions, made what we asked and lots of smiles. From reading my reviews, you can tell it means a lot. Listen, I make great food, have friends who bake and cook great food and on occasion will pay A LOT of money for great food and always great service even if food was just good will bring me back and have me raving to others.

I highly recommend, it's a great place!
author: Eddy L.

description:
This place represented everything people have come to love and expect from an authentic Japanese Kaiten sushi place. 

It's easy enough to understand, fascinating enough to draw in tourists. The plates are placed on a conveyor belt revolving around a "bar" with each colored plate a different price. I had been searching for fresh Uni since the beginning of my trip in SF and pleased to see they had box of Uni Sashimi for $10. (About 8 pieces or so) Any sushi lover will know that's a real bargain.

The other fish sushi plates were extremely fresh and chefs were in constant motion trying to meet the demand of a very crowded restaurant. Constant smiles and laughter were a good indication of great quality food and service.

Staff were extremely polite, sincerely apologizing if they had a delay on any requests. Windows, table top and floor were clean. (You'd be shocked at the amount of sushi restaurants that's out there filthier than a frat house restroom...)

All in all, I was full from fresh fish and high quality rice coming out to $30 (after 20% tip). 

Very happy, would come back when I visit again in the future.
author: A S.

description: This place is consistent. Yummy sushi at reasonable price. Sushi chefs behind the bar give great customer services, always polite!
author: secilia c.

description:
When you come at peak hours, the fish is really fresh. The cuts are really nice for the most part. Don't waste your money on the uni though. It's definitely not the kind of uni you're looking for. Uni should be sweet and taste like the sea and not..bitter. 

Well, it's cheap. Hahah. 

This place is not terrible and I really like that.
author: Margaret S.

description:
I've walked by this place so many times and can't believe this is the type of sushi place I've been looking for! I don't know why it's so difficult to find a sushi place with sushi boats! 

The prices are very reasonable!! I had 2 plates of the spider roll (total of 8 pieces all together), I shared a place of edamame with my best friend, (I forgot what she had) but the total was less than $15! Not bad! 

As for parking, I paid $4 for an hr and 6 mins! (Thanks a lot SFMTA) or you can park in the parking garage for $2/hr.
author: Ruby E.

description: It was Monday...  Ino Sushi was closed so I went to Tenroku.  Not bad for a revolving Sushi place and/or a quick bite before checking out a flick at nearby Sundance Kabuki Theatre.  Any place that uses surimi or imitation crabmeat and doesn't make their own tamago never gets 5 stars.  Next time I'll hit Warakubune for the revolving sushi boat-style experience.
author: Scott S.

description:
Pretty good quality sushi for a "sushi boat" style place. 

The atmosphere is great. I like that this place is small. It was also clean. 

The sushi chef's were very nice and service was great. 

I also love wondering around Japan town. Location is clutch, once you know how to get here! :)
author: Lauren S.

description:
Wow I am impressed for a new restaurant.  Compared to the other popular conveyor/boat sushi place in Japantown (Isobune) this is a huge upgrade.  I could rack up a bill from their Kobe beef nigiri alone.  Kobe.  Beef.  Nigiri.  Really thin slices of raw Kobe beef on rice.  Raw beef sounds gross but there you are eating raw fish so don't give me that look.  Yes it is that good without soy sauce or wasabi.  Yes that would be the only thing I ate here if given the option.  There is a nice variety of cooked and raw sushi served so everyone has something they can enjoy.  The specialty sushi on the menu are no joke, either.  Just remember the menu sushi are maki (rolls) so you get a lot.

Pro tip:  Be willing to wait.  Like many sushi boat/conveyor belt places it gets busy during peak meal times.
author: Christine L.

description:
I would venture to say that this might be the best sushi place I've ever been to. Normally, while I like the fun aspect of sushi boat / conveyor belt like experiences, I never expect the actual sushi to be of high quality. So, I was more than happy to be wrong in my expectations of this place. 

Not only was this a fun experience, being able to sit at the bar and seeing all the rolls and fish being prepared, but the sushi was delicious! We kept asking one of the sushi chefs to just hand us what was being prepared so we wouldn't have to fight the other patrons for the dishes or wait for them to come around! We had everything from blue shrimp, to mackarel (any self respecting Russian's sushi-go-to, except this had the caviar, which made it extra good), delicious tuna, salmon, yellow tail with cod liver, scallops which melted in my mouth... did I mention the mackarel? Also, the sashimi pieces were absolutely thicker than I'd ever seen (and again, delicious).

I don't think I can rave enough about this place! It was absolutely wonderful and I can't wait to come back!
author: Maria G.

description:
Visited with the boy last night, and was quite pleasantly surprised!  Conveyor sushi gets a bad rap, but this place was awesome.  The hosts/waitresses were very friendly and service was prompt - the sushi chefs were chatting and joking with the customers, and it was easy to get their attention if you wanted something but didn't see it out.

Also, the Toro special for $6 was a nice highlight - obviously not the most amazing toro I've ever had, but fantastic for the price.  Some item prices that I remember are below, overall I thought it was reasonably priced.

Ama ebi - $6
Sake - $4.5
Hamachi - $4.5
Toro - $6 (special, it's usually $12)
Uni Tray - $10 
Kappa Maki - $3

Definitely coming back!
author: Katie F.

description: This was my first time trying convener belt sushi and I'm glad I went with Tenroku Sushi. It's a great way to try many types of sushi without committing to a whole roll. The seared salmon nigiri was deliciously fatty and melts in your mouth.
author: Peng X.

description:
It was 8:30pm on Saturday and obviously packed everywhere.  We went to three restaurants and the wait was crazy and we ended up here.  Since this is a newly sushi boat restaurant, we just give it a try.  

The restaurant was full but luckily we only waited for 5 minutes to get two seats.  Everyone was very friendly and welcome. 

The quality of the fish was not too bad and the price range was reasonable.  However the selection of the dishes was not enough.  

Overall, not too bad if you want something quick and easy.
author: Liza T.

description: Very good place for a quick sushi fix. The Sushi is delivered via conveyor belt and is very fresh. Each plate is color coded and corresponds to their respective prices. There are about a couple dozen varieties of sushi that you can choose from; which were all very good. Service is very attentive and friendly.
author: Marco M.

description: Really friendly chef :) and decent price for sushi boat. (But chicken karage was so tiny... prob worse than pop corn chicken )
author: Yumi K.

description: Meh. pretty mediocre. Quick and friendly service but the best sushi or the best price. Rolls weren't particularly inventive. Also, very cramped- though clean and bright.  Isobune in the same building is a better bet.
author: Anna F.

description: This may have been the one of the worst if not the worst quality sushi restaurant in San Francisco. As someone who has lived in the Bay Area all my life, this may have been my least favorite experience. Before you think that you'll go, even though reading this, I'll save you the trouble. It's not worth the price of each plate. The rice was not flavorful, and neither was the sashimi. If you're looking for a similar restaurant close by with better sushi and better prices, GO TO ISOBUNE WHICH IS ALSO IN THE MALL.
author: Brian K.

description: The food was excellent, great variety and prices are not bad, the ambience reminds me of Japan.
author: Jorge P.

description:
Really liked this place for the sushi. Comes on a belt COVERED. Reminded me of some of the places in hong kong. Chef was Mexican offered me fresh toro - its was like butter. So good. 

I think this place is better than the geary st sushi on belt but not as good as isobune. Given the price, this place is in the middle. I will definitely come back. I hope they will open till 10pm in the future and not 9.30.
author: Thomas C.

description: Fast but not very fresh.  I feel a bit queasy during and afterwards.  The unagi sauce is a little sickly-sweet.  Still edible but not great.
author: Niniane W.

description: The quality of food at this place disappoints but the service sure did make up for it. I was so excited to try their box of I believe called Hokkaido Uni for just 10 bucks but I also should've expected it wasn't too great for such a cheap price. I turned out disappointed cus it just wasn't fresh. My friend and I also had an order of salmon nigiri, kobe beef nigiri, o-toro nigiri, snow roll and a cherry blossom roll I believe that's what is call. Everything was just okay cus I definitely had way better. The only good food in our whole late lunch was the fresh oysters but of course, I've also had better elsewhere. I wouldn't come back after a one time try but I would recommend to those who haven't try it yet to experience a one time try. Service was definitely attentive since we did go for late lunch around 2, it wasn't busy at all. The lady comes around here and then to refill your tea and ask if you're doing okay but that should be expected in the food service industry. Overall, decent food for quite a decent price.
author: Joey L.

description: This place is new and it looked pretty packed so we thought we'd check it out.  I can't speak for the sushi but the staff was attentive and the soups are amazing! Maybe it was a cold day and maybe it was my stomach telling me it was time to eat but I would definitely come back.  Judging by the crowd I would say the feeling's mutual.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Okay, so it's a little pricey but this is really delicious sushi! We ordered off the menu AND grabbed a few plates as they circled the sushi bar while we awaited our order.
This is all beautifully presented and enhanced with exquisitely patterned sauces surrounding the sushi. 
When we ordered two rolls apiece, the friendly chef advised us that was too much but we know our appetites when it comes to sushi - we LOVE, LOVE, LOVE good sushi!
The waitress was really on it, promptly removing empty plates, refilling our tea, water, or other beverages, bringing extra napkins, or educating us on the types of plated sushi circling around.
This was a great dining experience with nice, respectful, and welcoming people...
author: Kay B.

description:
Tenroku is okay for a quick bite, but there are so many options in J-town for a much better meal. Decided to try this conveyor belt sushi place since I was shopping in the area. Their sign saying $6 for O-toro is what drew me in.

I tried:
- Gomae
the flavour of the sauce was a bit watered down
- O-toro
the cut is too thick and I've had way better / fresher (at twice the price tho)
- Grilled cod
you can't go wrong with cod. This was lightly seasoned so the flavour of the fish stood out.
- Amaebi
it's not sweet amaebi that I'm used to.

Both the O-toro and amaebi were too big - I prefer the fish sliced thinner.  It seems the aim here is bigger portions for okay-ish quality. This is more for a beginner sushi diner looking for the novelty of conveyor belt sushi.
Staff was very attentive and quick... they deserve a few stars for that.

2.5 stars
author: Daphne L.

description:
This is a great spot for a quick sushi bite!

I personally don't have a gripe about japanese restaurants run by Chinese peeps,
there are so many that it's hard to keep count. Heck, even the Japanese Tea Garden
is filled with Chinese waitresses! That said, let's move onto the rest:
- Good selection of fun american rolls as well as nigiri
- Fish I've had has always been fresh 
- Consistent service and food any day of the week
- Friendly staff, tea constantly refilled without asking

It stacks pretty well against Isobune, which is only located on the other side of the bridge.
The presentation is better, staff is nicer, seats aren't as crammed, and I prefer
eating in a well-lit, clean environment with nice and clean floors.
Prices aren't all that higher, so my preference has been to come to Tenroku instead.
They have updated their price sheet to include a $2.5 black plate for tamago and edamame,
as well as directions on what to do with all those lids.. please put them aside instead
of back onto the conveyor belt (I think this comes after having too many pile-up accidents).

If you're trying to find it, it's across from the bookstore, right by the bridge, hard to miss!
author: Jade T.

description:
First time here. Tried this place because one of my friend don't eat raw fish but everyone else wanted sushi boat. Chinese owned. Everyone was speaking Cantonese. I liked the newly remodeled place. bright and clean (but maybe a little too bright). Little plastic covers over your sushi was a plus. We've been to places where we put sushi covers back on the conveyor belt. So my friend had placed her first cover back on the conveyor belt and happily continued on with our conversation. But then, we got cut off by the sushi man immediately. He removed it from the belt and asked her to leave it on her table next time; causing everyone to look at us like we're stupid. I understand each restaurant runs differently and we respect that. However, I wish they would have placed a sign or at least have the waitress instruct us on what to do with the plastic covers; instead of giving us the dirty look. 

The fish there is okay. Some tasted fresh and some didn't. The uni and unagi is very good.  There was this one nigiri with seared white fish and ankimo on top; it tasted so bad i couldn't finish the rest. It did not taste like fish! Maybe because it was seared, it had a plastic taste to it. The fish tartar looked nice topped with caviar but the fish did not taste fresh. The green onions in it tasted as if it was chopped on an unwashed cut board, giving it an extra bit of unwanted flavor of ginger, garlic, and onions. The Tamago nigiri was a joke! Lots of fancy new sushi ideas. I usually like new ideas but some of these just did not tasted good. Just give me some "real" sushi please.

Overall, everything was ok. Most likely not returning. Sorry, but I rather go to Isobune...
author: R C.

description: This is the best conveyor belt sushi in SF! It is delicious -- super fresh, the staff is friendly, and the prices are great. Get the kobe beef -- it will melt in your mouth!
author: Betty W.

description: Love this place. It's usually quite busy, so the sushi is fresh. The portions are big and delicious. There's a lot of variety, and you can also order from the menu. Service is polite and efficient. I keep coming here after my crossfit class when I'm starving.
author: Heidi L.

description: Really nice. Clean and good food. Not that big resturant but we got good seats. I really can recommend this restaurant.
author: Mikael M.

description:
I am so sad to say that this place has the worst ramen ever. I loved their sushi so I thought I would give ramen a try. I ordered tonkatsu ramen. The soup base tasted like nothing and wasn't worth $11 at all. 

Good service though.
author: Helen L.

description:
I have been going to Isobune for years and I have seen their quality dropped but their customer service is still good. So I gave this place a try, I like the waiting time  because only 10 mins and we got our seat for 4 and Isobune will take more then 30 minutes.
Let's talk about the things I don't like, 1. The sushi rice is hard, fish quality is not good (can't have high expectations sine the highest cost is $6 per plate). 
2. Chinese Sushi chef with eye glasses talks perverted and insulting jokes regarding woman's private with his chinese customers (friends).
3. Customer service F-, only one waitress have a smile and it's not the one with the uniform. They don't seem to understand that their job is to served their customers,  to get things for them.
4. To top it off, they suggested 18% 20% and 25% tips, I mean omfg. You have to EARN IT.

It was my first time there and definity will be my last.

We had udon afterwards at mifune.

anyway,  I still wish you guys success but you guys need a lot of work. From the top down.
author: uncle m.

description:
Love the variety of sushi plus they have a full menu. Really fresh and high quality seafood.  Excellent and attentive service.
Plus the conveyor belt kept my girls busy the whole time!
author: Grace T.

description: Got my vote. Great sushi boat, reasonably priced, taste good, good variety too. Will definitely be back. I'm so glad that this place is here, it's so hard to find a good sushi boat place.
author: Arlene R.

description: I've come here a few times.  The sushi was fine, not very high quality.  However the last visit may be my last because I didn't get any service.  I asked how long was the wait for one person.  The sever repeated my question and just walked away.  WTF?  So I stood there for about 5 min and walked away.
author: Stan V.

description:
Friendliest staff ever! And so attentive. 

Good prices. Good sushi. BEAUTIFUL plating and presentation. 

They could do with a few more types of sushi on the boat but I know they just opened so maybe they haven't quite gotten into the groove of keeping up with demand yet? 

I would definitely eat here again.
author: Aubrie D.

description:
Love this place !  Much batter then regular Suchi boat restaurant i go. Nice unique rolls
Fresh fish and CHEAP TORO ! Only 6$ for 2pc . This is lowest price I ever paid for toro

4 season and Mexican tools my favorite 
Good service .. Good chef
author: Scott L.

description: We went for a simple lunch during non peak hours. We will def return sometime and if the service and food is just as fabulous, I'd happily up this to 5 stars. Staff was friendly and I really loved the two young chefs behind the counter, so kind and all smiles. I ordered only vegetarian and the vegetable to rice ratio was perfect. Thanks for the great midday treat!
author: CatBut T.

description: I've been here twice and I can only give 3 stars. I sat down for the sushi boat both times and didn't see or ever order anything from their menu, so I can't say anything about those items. I can say that their sushi is alright though. The fish are fresh, but they can be left out for a while. Some of their rolls also stay in rotation for a bit too, so they get a little soggy or whatever, but I guess it's still good. Sushi's like pizza, even if it's bad, it's still sushi, right? That's how I feel about this place. It's decent, and considering Isobune kinda went lower quality, there aren't too many options for great sushi boating. This is definitely sufficient for sushi boating. The wait isn't long and the prices are fair. All in all, it's really just another sushi boat place, but it's worth trying!
author: Holly P.

description: Best sushi in Japan town. Reasonable price. Highly recommended.
author: Parinamana M.

description: Sushi was fresh and tasted fine. The place was busy when we went, which I take as a good sign at a sushi restaurant. We helped ourselves to the conveyor sushi but also ordered a few things off the menu, and they always arrived very quickly. The price is fine considering all the variety you get with the stuff from the conveyor. I was very excited to see takoyaki come across the conveyor belt, so we snatched it up quickly, but I was very sad to find that it wasn't cooked properly; however, the waitress removed that plate from our bill without issue.
author: P U.

description: This place is incredible.  The service is so friendly and the food is great for the price.  I have to say if I am ever in San Francisco again I will be traveling here even if it's out of the way.  So worth it.
author: Steve T.

description: Best sushi boat restaurant in San Francisco.  So much variety, fresh fish and delicious rolls. Fresh and good quality fish for the price, so much better than Isobune.  Why would anyone go to Isobune after they have dined at Tenroku! Beats me
author: Mit T.

description:
I always get weary about sushi boat type places as I've been to a couple of bad ones. I always see the same plates go by uneaten and with the occasional fly lingering around.

BF took me here just to look. I wanted to eat here right away since the fresh looking nigiri on the conveyor looked so yummy. Plus I love nigiri.

I got really excited and picked up two dishes right when we sat down. The fish on top of the rice was a good size. They took all of my requests from the menu because I didn't see them on the conveyor. 

Service was prompt. They were so swift that I never noticed who came by each time and took the plastic lids. Also, in my opinion, the plastic lids kept the food clean.

I ate a lot. At times I had three plates in front of me. It's so easy to eat like a pig here. What I got...all nigiri.

*True Toro - That's what they called it. Soft and buttery and the marbling was nice. I ate three orders of this.

*Hotate - Pretty good. The scallops were a bit too cold though. I ate two orders of this.

*Albacore - Had some garlic on top and texture melted.

*Amaebi - Just okay. It was too cold and the kinda too bouncy in texture.

*Butterfish - Tried it and it's a pass for me. It was a bit rough.

*O-Toro - Not bad, although I liked the real tuna better. 

Other things my bf got:

*California roll - Good...not much to say about a California roll.

*Tamago - Apparently super good since bf had like 5 plates of them.

*Salmon - Didn't try this.

I don't remember all of the things he ate since I was busy stuffing face. I shall come back. Too bad it's so far out of the way for me.
author: Regina W.

description: Best sushi in japantown, i used to go to isobune but after i try this, isobune cant even be compared with this. My suggestion is to ask the chef for a seared salmon belly and hamachi special. They are both my favorites
author: Reza G.

description:
Came and was seated right away. The tea was extremely watered down. My friend and I looked at the sushi boats and we decided to give it a try based off of the reviews we read on Yelp. Nope nope nope. The one Ikura sushi had a texture that screamed not fresh. We decided to give them one chance and ordered the beef tataki. Approximately 15 minutes later we were sorely disappointed. For $20 we did not expect 8 measly thinly sliced beef slices that weren't even prepared properly. Real beef tataki is cold in the middle and quickly seared on both sides. Their beef tataki was just beef that had been sliced way too thin and basically a chewy raw, doused with ponzu sauce. 

Sushi: NOT FRESH
Price: OVERPRICED
Verdict: Not coming back ever again. Save your money and go to Isobune!
author: Rinslet W.

description:
yey for kaiten sushi! loved it! nice big cuts of sashimi, decent variety. didn't get sick after :) the ingredients taste fresh and fast turnarounds. limited seats around the sushibar which is just the way it should be. 
i would definitely come back again when i'm in the area craving sushi. quick and easy.
author: Ai L.

description:
Pricing: Good-Expensive. We split $20/person, which is about right for sushi.
Quality: Good. We really should not have come in during a dead hour...
Turnaround: Good-Excellent. Given that we were practically the only customers.
Service: Good-Excellent. Since we were the only customers.

Like any Japanese sushi restaurant, the pricing is kind of expensive, but expected. Not to mention I get to play around with a sushi boat conveyor belt so the little kid inside of me is happy. Unfortunately, we came during an off hour around 2pm and we were the only customers minus a couple who came in just as we were finishing up. This meant that a lot of the sushi has been rolling around for quite a few rounds and we could see the discoloration, especially in the tuna. However, the salmon looked fresher and tasted fine. Not to mention that since we were the only customers, I was allowed to keep asking the chefs to make rolls just for us too so we did not have to eat the non-fresh ones on the belt. They were chopping up things like green onions, but happily obliged to make me unagi nigiri when asked. The woman who came to refill our tea often even personally brought out fresh unagi from the kitchen for us too.
author: Jenny W.

description:
This review is only for udon and spicy tuna roll.

I came here at 12 noon on Friday. There were only a few people here. The staff is very nice. I ordered a chicken udon and spicy tuna roll.

Spicy tuna roll: 6 pieces for $5. Tastes pretty standard. 3 stars

Chicken udon $7: The soup came shortly after. It comprised of lightly salted boiled dark chicken, mushrooms, carrots, some greens, and of course, the udon. Nothing special again. 3 stars.

The service is really good. There were more workers than customers. They came and filled my tea three times, and one time it was still full. I would give the service 5 stars.

Overall, I would give this restaurant 3.25 stars. They are great on service and presentation, but they lack the quality.
author: Jed H.

description: Delicous! I was ready for terrible quality from a conveyor belt sushi, but it was high quality. They were full on a Friday night with a line waiting outside. There were enough interesting maki pieces that I didn't feel like it was the same old same old. They were also very artistically made. And the did a great job combining different types of fish and, my favorite, avocado! Only downside is it's a little pricer than if you went somewhere and ordered whole rolls, but here you do get to try a bunch of different kinds. And not bad on pricing for SF area.
author: Chani P.

description:
This is my second review about this amazing restaurant!
Me and my wife discovered this place in Autumn 2014 and, since then, we have been having our "Sushi Friday" EVERY week and ONLY at Tenroku. That's one of the most exciting day of the week for me and I literally count the days until we can finally go back there for dinner.
Food is always fresh and prepared in front of you with particular attention to detail by the chefs, prices are very affordable compared to other "all you can eat" Japanese restaurants in SF and the waitress and the owner are always kind and super fast. Also, the tea that they offer is so tasty, but also sooo hot (so we usually have to wait until the end before we can drink it). 
I hardly believe/understand the authenticity and fairness of those few 2-3 stars reviews.
Tenroku almost became as a family for us: an appointment that we can't and we don't wanna miss. Another proof of their being exceptional is that, although the restaurant is often very crowded and we just go there once a week, both the chefs and the owner remember what me and my wife like to eat and drink (Strawberry Ramune for me, Philly Rolls for my wife).
Everytime I eat at Tenroku I feel totally happy and I giggle like a child all evening but, as for every pleasant moment, Friday nights end too soon (I admit it's very difficult to stop myself from devouring almost all food that appears on the conveyor belt!).
After having been a customer for months and having tried almost all of Tenroku dishes (I wrote "almost" because every week they always add something new), I confirm my 5 STARS. 
Just because, as I wrote in my previous review, I can't rate them more! :)
author: Laura B.

description: We've been dining at this cozy sushi place ever since they opened. Great service and good food :)
author: Vin G.

description: We come here fairly regularly. The sushi is fresh. The sushi chefs are friendly and accommodating, and the wait staff is good. It is also kid friendly. We bring our four year old here all the time and she loves it.
author: Allison C.

description: Nice quality at a reasonable price. I've stopped in here a few times for a mid-week meal. They have a few things you don't find at Isobune down the hallway and the price is definitely a little bit better. The service is very friendly and attentive. You're sitting close enough to the guys preparing the sushi that they occasionally double check to be sure everything is OK. All in all a solid place to go for a nice dinner.
author: Gerry M.

description:
I'm going to start off by saying: Folks, manage your expectations.  If you're expecting mind-blowing Japanese food, I'd say pay for it and head over to Morimoto's in Napa or some other fancy joint.  But if you're looking for a solid lunch meal, stop by and give it a try.

The food was solid. I wasn't feeling very adventurous today so I had the chicken udon and an avocado roll; my folks did the revolving sushi bar and kept raving about the uni and ika that Miguel prepared for them.  I thought the chicken was well-done and the broth was delicious in my udon. 

The servers were attentive and I always had a full mug of green tea.  The pricing was not bad for SF and the most expensive sushi bar option was a $6 plate NOT $10 as some reviewers have stated.  They also keep a separate menu for more complex rolls and other items like udon and bento boxes.

Overall, this place was clean, the sushi varied, and the staff friendly.  It's a small place, so be ready to brush shoulders if it's a full house.  Goodbye Isobune, hello Tenroku! 

Tip: Arrive as soon as they open: the chefs make the sushi fresh in front of you and don't stop until the entire conveyor belt is full (regardless of whether the restaurant is full or not).  Also the chefs are much more obliged to make exactly what you want when the restaurant isn't too full.
author: Jess A.

description: I'm paying the check right now and I had to give a bad rating because of the absolutely horrible service. The waitress completely ignored simple things like bringing us water and when she had no choice but to give us attention she gave us so much attitude it was amazing. This is the second time it's happened to us here at this restaurant. Unacceptable.
author: Helen L.

description:
I didn't like the seafood udon and it gets one star for at least coming out hot. They really botched the soup and it was watery with a layer of oil on top. There was also a huge amount of vegetables compared to the actual seafood in there. The small piece of octopus had a poor, overcooked texture of a piece of rubber. It was hard to chew into and reminded me of a hardened wad of gum. The broccoli was insanely bitter and hard. I literally couldn't eat it because it tasted so foul. The same applied for the carrots floating around - they were sweet, but mostly bitter after sitting in the broth. As for the udon noodles, they were fine, but there wasn't that much in the bowl, so after a few slurps, there was mostly terrible broth left. I felt ripped off paying $10 for it. I might as well have gotten a vegetarian udon or use that money to get sushi.

That being said, I'll review the sushi since that's what Tenroku is all about: conveyor belt sushi. For conveyor belt sushi, it was alright, but I think it's a hit or miss. The prices are quite expensive and I could've bought full rolls for the more pricey plates between $5-7 which only offer 2-3 pieces of sushi. The cheaper plates will start at $3, but they contain the mediocre California roll pieces and inari sushi (rice wrapped in tofu skin). There wasn't any seaweed salad, gyoza, or other sushi pieces besides the old sashimi cuts and the same four rolls (salmon with lemon, eel, spicy crab, and crunchy shrimp). The point of conveyor belt sushi is to offer a variety and showcase sample plates at a cheap price, so Tenroku fails at that. The fish didn't seem too fresh for what I was paying either. They made too much of the same stuff and no one was taking the plates, which meant some of the fish that passed by, especially the sashimi, was heavily oxidized.

I came in and the place was empty besides a couple in the back corner. The waitress seemed to be a nice girl, but she was playing on her phone when I walked up to her, which screams, "I don't want to be professional nor do I care." She also loved hanging out at the front desk area because after seating me and my partner in the back corner, I'd have to walk repeatedly to the front to ask her for a water refill. (Hey, I find it rude to yell across the room considering the center is a kitchen.) Miguel is a really nice chef though and if you ask, he'll make whatever you want. I suggest doing this because you're guaranteed a fresh roll rather than a stagnant roll which has seen better times. Overall, the meal cost $50 for two people, which was painful considering the food wasn't too good nor was anything about Tenroku impressive. I think Tenroku is meant to be a normal sit-down restaurant, but the conveyor belt is a tourist gimmick to help it stand out.
author: Diana L.

description: Decent sushi place that run by chinese but in Japan town. This is SF and you need to expect that. Even the fishermen wharf crab vendors are all owned by Asians. It's setup as sushi boat inside. They have a couple of tables outside. It's not the place where you will take a large group.
author: Jeff O.

description: Sushi boat is so fun...and so dangerous.  Thankfully for my bank account, there aren't too many great sushi boat places in the city.....except for Tenroku.  I've been to a couple of sushi boat places around the city and neither of them were all that spectacular.  I've always had this image in my mind that sushi boat places were gimmicky and/or a tourist trap, especially in SF.  But Tenroku breaks that image for me.  They offered a wide variety of fish, more than just your typical tuna, salmon and shrimp.  They offered yellowtail topped with monkliver (SO GOOD, probably grabbed 3 plates of those), toro, Uni, takoyaki and various creative rolls.  You can also order some stuff off the menu, but thats no fun.  Pricing of the plate range from about $2.50 - $7 although there is a sign for a $10 plate thats black and has flowers on it, but i never saw one on the conveyor belt.  Service was great, sushi chefs greet you and were always asking if everything was ok during our meal.  They even gave us a warm hot towel right when we sat down.  The place isnt very big, its a very cozy atmosphere but its fun.  Sit down and start grabbin plates.  If you see something you might be interested in, just grab it, it may not make it around the conveyor belt the 2nd time around.  Especially if I'm there.
author: Darren W.

description: I totally don't understand why they have those plastic lids, but the servings are big and fresh.
author: Stacy C.

description: Delicious! Much better quality than Isobune. Great pieces and prices. Very good variety of maki and nigiri.
author: Samantha H.

description:
I'm a huge fan of the quickness and selection of sushi here. I appreciate that it's pretty a authentic to a Japanese sushi bar (there are no absurd boats) but there are little lids, which I super appreciate. Best when there are a lot of people so nothing gets stale, but seriously, you can get a few really great pieces. Nothing exotic. 
Only thing I wish is that I wish it were easier to flag down one of the sushi chefs to get a custom piece or two. Oh well.
author: Amy L.

description: I am very impressed with this restaurant! The experience was very pleasant and all the food we ordered was delicious and exceptionally prepared. I have eaten at many of the restaurants in Japan Town and this new restaurant pleasantly surprised me.
author: Jeremy S.

description: As far as sushi boat goes this place is pretty good, has a variety you can order, and decent price for being in jtown. I personally like it more than the other sushi boat in the building though it is a bit smaller, it doesn't seem to get too crazy packed
author: Dang L.

description: The best conveyor belt sushi we've ever tried. Do not hurry, just wait to see everything, they add new plates continuously. We usually take yellow to orange plates. Good choice of simple and sophisticated sushi. Visited this place many times, definitely will come back in the future.
author: Stas K.

description: This is a Chinese operated Japanese sushi boat resto.   The fishes were that fresh and not that exciting at all.  Ordered a chicken karage, but taste more like popcorn chicken from Quiekly!
author: Deb L.

description: wowie wow! we got there on a monday and literally the first people there...it was DELICIOUS. the chef was generous and gave me a free sample for my birthday. he also warned us a party of about 6 that just walked in were going to be LOUD...that was really nice of him. fab place. the fish slices are VERY generous and top notch quality.
author: Ellie B.

description: If you want good sushi, don't come here. Plain and simple. The only reason why I gave this place two stars is because the chef was nice. And I was their only customer.
author: Saki N.

description: Other place is much better.  Kinda pricey for what u get.   And please just greet people in English.. the pseudo Japanese is annoying.  The sushi chef is a nice guy.
author: Demanding T.

description: Service was perfectly attentive. Food was good and fresh. Sit in the middle as opposed to the ends. Good is put on conveyor belt in the middle so you will get your pick of the litter. Went to pay bill and forgot money at hotel. spoke to the owner and left to get wallet. She was very sweet and understanding. you can't always trust everyone, but she did trust me. I'll definitely go back.
author: Jeremy S.

description: This place is phenomenal!! Great sushi, really fresh and tasty. And just an overall fun way to eat some sushi! Definitely will be coming back. Very attentive service as well.
author: Melissa R.

description: Went to this place after hearing positive word of mouth. Was perfectly happy to sit at the counter and watch the sushi prep. Everything was very tasty. The quality of the fish was above average to excellent. Would come back again in a heartbeat.
author: B N.

description:
This place is terrific and definitely the best "sushi boat" experience I've had outside of Tokyo! 

Here are something things to keep in mind:

1) Quality
The quality here is good. It is not the level of quality you'll get paying $50 for a 10-piece omakase but I'd be hard pressed for pay the prices Tenroku charges and get better quality elsewhere. When there are lots of people the chefs are always putting fresh sushi on the conveyor belt so things are less likely to sit at busy times. 

2) Cost
We had mostly plates that ran $3-$4 each (for 2 pieces) except for the amazing scallon nigiri which was $5.50. For two people a dinner with a nice hot sake and enough sushi to really fill you up will probably run $60-70 for two... For the quality the prices are fair or even below market! 

3) Environment
This place is much nicer (more airy and more clean) than the other sushi boat place in the Japan center (Isobune). Importantly you don't feel like you're sitting low reaching up to the sushi boats. At Tenroku the sushi passes right at hand level - to keep this hygienic they use clear plastic lids on the plates. Would be more "Hirojuku style" without them but I'm glad for the cleanliness.

4) Service -- the waitresses and chefs are all super friendly and nice. 

5) Reservations -- not sure if you can but try to get them or come at slightly off hours because the secret is out about this place.

All in all awesome place and I look forward to going back soon!
author: dr r.

description: Probably one of the better sushi places in Japantown. We were hesitant to eat here because the prices were a bit too good to be true in some ways. A board of uni for $10? It was fresh and delicious. Toro for $6? Maybe not as fat as isobune, the other sushi boat place but it is pretty darn good. What I like about this place are there seared fish. There are seared walu with uni, seared hamachi with ankimo, and other fishes. All in all, I like this place and we plan on coming back.
author: Pierre L.

description: The Eclipse roll is interesting and not bad, as was the Mexican Desert roll. However, every plate of sushi that sailed by (pardon the pun) looked unappetizing, which is why we went to the menu. Average tempura. Good service.
author: Maximillian M.

description: This is a great go-to sushi restaurant, especially for those who don't want to spend lots of time waiting for the food. It is half self-served as you can either have your sushi from the belt or ask for a more specialized ones from the attentive sushi chefs. Ask for the seared salmon belly or hamachi special. Overall, it offers fine sushi considering the price.
author: Harvey T.

description: Amazingly fresh and quality is superb.  Prices are fair.  Will definitely come back soon.
author: Marlon T.

description: Surprisingly the ramen caught my eye here. My friend ordered the beef ramen and when it came it was pretty big so we shared a bit. It was really freakin' good considering that it was a conveyor belt sushi restaurant. The broth was flavorful but light and did not over power the other ingredients which was how I think ramen should be. Try it you will be surprised. The interior was clean, elegant and simple giving a nice relaxing atmosphere to eat and chat. The food is pretty fresh for the price and all made very carefully giving a very nice presentation of the food. The staff was friendly, very helpful, and clean and the chefs were very nice, easy to talk to, and respectful. They were not pushy or gave any attitude to us even though we came in around an hour and a half before closing. Try it for yourself.
author: Edward T.

description: Great sushi, great entrees, and great service! Mandy, Carmen,and the entire staff are very friendly and accommodating!
author: Andrew D.

description: This is a conveyor belt sushi restaurant, but don't let that turn you off. The fish here is really fresh and the rolls are tasty. The prices are really reasonable too and the service is excellent. I've been here a couple of times and will be back for moe
author: Vanessa D.

description: To me, this is the wrong place to have conveyor-place sushi place with Isobune (the sushi boat place) located just down the hallway.  The prices here seem higher for comparable items with less selection and the sushi isn't any better.  However, I'll give them three stars just for the good service, especially with one of the young lady server who was there when I visited (which was Tuesday evening last week) being very sweet and cute.
author: H K.

description: I have been in many sushi restaurants and had finally found the best sushi and service. Very good, nice decorated, tasty, amazing. LOVE SUSHI!!!!! BEST FOOD EVER!
author: Esmeralda N.

description:
Such a great place to have pick your own sushi. Chefs are soo friendly and sushi is really good quality. 

Great experience!
author: Renee S.

description: Came here once and I actually thought that they were not bad. The staff was very friendly. We were chatting about something I'm not sure what it was but they were very friendly. They looked like they just opened. They have floating sushi, conveyer belt sushi. I had uni and it was good, the same as any other ones that I've had. What's going good for this place is that they have a very nice clean and bright atmosphere inside.
author: J C.

description: Went in around 5. The restaurant is very small and only two people were sitted in there. The staff is nice but the menu is very limited. Nothing special. I would not go again.
author: Vicky Z.

description: Sashimi are fresh !!! Compare to their prices , they have pretty good choices of sushi/sashimi ! 4 stars to the quality of their foods . Customer service average I would say 4 stars as well . Will come back next time but better not on weekends !
author: Bobo N.

description: Sushi is decent for the price, which is reasonable, but the place is poorly run. I was just sitting down on one of their tall stools and as I am sitting one of the chefs calls to me and hands in my direction what appeared to be a long dish for soy sauce with gari. I lean forward to grab it from him, the stool tilts forward to the point that I start to lose my balance, and what looked like one dish was actually two and one of them got dropped during the handoff.  Meanwhile my natural reaction is to try to catch the dish, and my stool almost tips completely over in the process. Maybe wait until your customers are seated before precariously shoving things at them over an absurdly wide counter, or better yet, have the waitress or hostess place the sauce dishes down from the other side. And speaking of those waitresses, they frequently sneak up behind you and without saying anything (so that you know they are there) they reach right in front of your face while you are eating or talking to your companion, forcing you to dodge the dish covers that they are removing mere inches from your nose. Seriously - I realize that this is a quick service restaurant, and I've eaten in plenty of similar establishments in Tokyo, but the management of this place has really dropped the ball on training their staff.
author: Jonathan G.

description: Loved this place.  I had the best mini date with my husband here.  We were enjoying Japantown with my two big kids, newborn and my parents and we asked my parents if we could run off for 15 minutes.  We sat down, got some amazing stuff, paid and left.  I can't wait to go back when we have more time to eat everything there!
author: Amy A.

description: This place is way better than Isobune. The fish is fresh, the lighting is bright and the service is great. They also have some fun rolls that I have never heard of before. Will definitely come back.
author: Keromi K.

description: After a little shopping...decided to hit Japantown. All sushi and dishes ordered were great! Favorites were the ramen noodles and the deep fried squid legs. Angela was a very attentive and pleasant server! I look forward to returning!
author: Osugradinca S.

description:
If you do eat here, keep this in mind
- CHECK YOUR BILL BEFORE YOU PAY. 
- They do not know or apply "the customer is always right".
- It is run by Chinese people, NOT japanese.
- Sushi is cheap but it makes you wonder
- Udon is loaded with MSG

The sushi is cheap and eatable but the waitresses need English comprehension lessons.   Ordered a bunch of sushi, seafood udon for my son (huge but tons of MSG), and a combo dinner of salmon teriyaki and shrimp tempura, which is all listed on one page.  I pointed to the items as I ordered since she obviously didn't understand my sushi order unless I pointed to the items on the menui.  When we got the bill, she charged the shrimp tempura as an appetizer ($8 vs. $5).  At any other restaurant they would say, my mistake I will adjust.  She then proceeds to lecture me that I did not tell her that.  I state I told you as a combo and pointed it on the menu.  She obviously was new and didn't know the menu so I turned to the page in front of the manager and told her look.  It's here on the bottom and I pointed to it.  She kept insisting I didn't.  I told her if that is how you feel we will just take the $3 difference off your tip.  She said "that was fine".  In the meantime, I heard her manager tell her in Chinese the difference between the combo and the appetizer.  HELLO?!

My husband initially tipped 15% vs. our standard 20%.  Upon bringing us a leftover box, she once again insisted I should tell her more clearly next time, so we dropped her tip to 10%.  

There are a ton better places to eat with much better service.  The sushi place before this one had bad service as well so I guess the bad service karma continues!
author: A C.

description: Great place for high-quality, great sushi, and wonderful service all at an affordable price! The sushi conveyor belt includes toro(fatty tuna) usually very expensive, but only 6.50 here! It's the best place to have sushi for a quick lunch. Also they half salmon belly, yellowtail belly, and all these great tasting things! It's like going to a fancy japan restaurant eating sushi :)
author: Ashley C.

description: I am Japanese and have found a few places that have blown me away with their tasty sushi. Not only is this a super fun way to eat sushi, it is so delicious! I love the chefs who work in the middle. They are very social. They check on how we like the nigiri and if you ask for something in particular, they are more than happy to make it. Be sure to try out their chef special hamachi. It's to die for! Best sushi in the Japantown mall!
author: Paul H.

description: environment is clean and service is good. however the toro and the uni were not as good as i had hoped. and not surprisingly i walked out not that full as i wasnt in full splurge mode. overall decent but not great.
author: P M.

description: The price is fair, and the food quality is surprisingly good. They have a wide variety of sushi to choose, and a lot of new style sushi. Not as bored as the normal rolls all the time in typical Japanese restaurant in California. Their service is better than I expected.
author: Amy Y.

description: This place is brand new and AMAZING! The sushi was very fresh and delicious, and the head sushi chef even made us a couple of personal dishes of his creation. The service was fantastic, and everyone was extremely friendly. All the food and drink was well-balanced and tasty. Truly.
author: Gianne S.
